 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT GEORGIA Health Project I. THE HEALTH SECTOR A. Socio-economic Context 1.1. Georgia has a population of 5.4 million people in a geographical area of 70,000 square kilometers, bounded by the Black Sea, Russia, Azerbaijan, Armenia and Turkey. At the time of its independence, April 9, 1991, Georgia appeared to be a relatively well-off republic with fairly good growth potential. Since independence, however, Georgia has suffered from intense civil conflict. A large influx of refugees to the capital city (about 270,000) has worsened the economic plight of the country. In recent years, the Georgian economy has greatly been affected by the disruption in payments and trade within the FSU, by large trade shocks, and by output declines in Russia and elsewhere in the region. These factors have been further aggravated by the effects of weak financial policies after independence; a sharp economic decline and lowered standard of living are the result. 1.2. The Government has made progress towards restoring political stability and law and order. Since early 1994, it has focused on rebuilding the economy and has expressed a conmmitment to restoring macroeconomic stability while fostering the resumption of growth. To this end, a comprehensive program of macroeconomic stabilization and structural reforms has been implemented with the assistance of the IMF and the World Bank. Macroeconomic stabilization has made important advances: monthly inflation rates in April and May, 1995 were below 1 %, and the exchange rate remained stable throughout the year. In September, 1995, a new currency, the Georgian Lari, was introduced. The exchange rate with the US dollar has remained stable. Privatization of small-scale enterprises has accelerated since the second half of 1994. In 1995, the Government reduced by 35 % the number of positions in the budgetary sector. The Government has begun to make radical reforms in the administration and financing of activities which previously were fully publicly financed. It has made reforms not only in the public administration and civil service sectors, but also in social services. The Government intends to pursue steady implementation of health sector reform and to initiate education sector reforms as well. 1.3. The health status of the Georgian people is poor relative to the rest of Europe, and is deteriorating rapidly. In 1990, life expectancy was 68.1 for men and 75.7 for women, compared to 71 for men and 78 for women in Western Europe. The infant mortality rate (IMR) declined more than 50% in the past thirty years, but remained twice as high as that in Western European countries. One third of infant deaths occur in the first three days of life and, thus, could be prevented through better perinatal and neonatal care. The maternal mortality rate (MMR) is estimated to be more than four times higher than in Western European countries. Adult male mortality has become an increasing public health problem. Deaths due to cardio-vascular diseases have been higher than in Western Europe, contributing to lower life expectancy, especially among men.
 - 2 - 1.4. During the last five years, health conditions have further deteriorated. The IMR has risen 13%, reaching an estimated 21.4 (adjusted WHO definition) in 1993. Outbreaks of measles and diphtheria occurred in 1994 and tuberculosis is on the rise among children and adults. The MMR has increased and is expected to increase further, due to an increase in home deliveries. Deaths due to cardio-vascular diseases seem to have increased 35 % over the last five years and the overall age-adjusted mortality rate has risen by 18%. These trends suggest that average life expectancy has very likely fallen since 1992, but reliable data are not available. 1.5. The former health system did, however, have positive features. A strong network of hospitals and polyclinics was available and coverage was universal. Significant steps in controlling infectious diseases such as tuberculosis had been made. Indeed, the system may have been particularly adept at tackling health problems resulting from poverty and the environment. However, there is little doubt that the former system was characterized by severe imbalances and inefficiencies which need to be changed. 1.6. The Government is committed to reforming the health sector. Legislation passed in June 1995 and implemented that August produced important changes: (a) improvement of preventive public health services, a reduced role for State financing of clinical services, and a focus on strategic planning, monitoring and policy adjustment by the Ministry of Health; (b) a separation of provision from financing, effected by setting up a State Health Fund and regional agencies financed by government and municipal contributions and a wage based social security tax; (c) self- management of hospitals, with all staff paid by income generated solely by the institutions; (d) allocation of funds to municipalities on the basis of population size rather than on the basis of norms related to the supply of health services; and (e) the legitimization of previously illegal direct payments from users to providers, enabling the privatization of hospitals, polyclinics, dental clinics, as well as the import and distribution of pharmaceuticals, under effective and efficient government regulation. B. Health Sector Organization and Financing 1.7. The structure of health services is under transformation. Under the model inherited from the former Soviet Union, the organization, management and finance of health services were centrally coordinated through the Ministry of Health and services were delivered through a hierarchical referral system of more than 400 hospitals and 1,400 polyclinics and ambulatories. Nearly all of the country's approximately 25,000 physicians and 50,000 nurses were employees of the Ministry of Health. Under the reforms, however, many responsibilities will be decentralized to newly created health regions, institutions will be privatized and health sector staff removed from the Government payroll. 1.8. Decree 400, issued by the Head of State in December 1994 and later ratified by Parliament, lays the foundation of the health sector reforms. It establishes 12 health regions and creates two new regional institutions: regional hospitals, which will provide tertiary level in-patient care; and regional health funds (RHF), which will be responsible for ensuring that adequate services are delivered in the regions and processing and auditing requests for insurance payments from providers. A Cabinet of Minister's decree (June 1995) later ruled that all non-tertiary health care institutions would become administratively and financially autonomous from the State Budget.
 - 3 - 1.9. Privatization of health facilities is being administered by the Ministry of State Property Management. The regional hospitals will remain publicly owned. All other institutions are grouped into three categories: those required to maintain existing services levels for 10 years; those required to remain as health providers but with no specific service requirements; and those to be used however the new owner desires. Those required to maintain existing service levels will be offered first to an association of personnel working inside the institution, and only subsequently, if the personnel are unwilling (or unable) to buy the institution, will it be put up for auction. The first phase of privatization has begun, and targets more than 700 dental clinics and pharmacies. This will be followed by 500 polyclinics in early 1996 and a number of small hospitals in mid-1996. The Government's targets for privatization are included in the Statement of Development Objectives (Annex A, para 20). Facilities which are not purchased would be liquidated by July, 1998. 1.10. As part of the reforms introduced in early 1995, approximately 120,000 employees of the health sector have been gradually removed from the Government payroll between August and December, 1995. Those that remain in public facilities are paid directly by the now managerially independent hospitals and clinics. 1.11. Under the former system, health care services were primarily financed from the government budget. Localities were allocated funds using a formula based on the number of hospital beds and physicians. A limited number of facilities were financed and partly controlled by state enterprises and through parallel systems provided by other Ministries such as Railways and Defense. With the collapse of the economy, government revenues decreased sharply between 1991 to 1994 and the private sector has become the major source of revenue for the health sector. In place of the former system of public services, an unregulated amalgam of public and private services arose. While most services continued to be provided in public facilities, patients paid for all aspects of treatment, including drugs, supplies, and provider fees. Consequently, between 1990 and 1993 the average number of outpatient visits per person per year fell from 10 to 5. In the absence of an adequate household expenditure survey, it is not possible to give a credible estimate of the total value of private expenditures. The amount may, however, total as much as 75 percent of total sector expenditures. 1.12. The government's policy response to increase revenues for the sector has been to introduce a mandatory payroll tax for health with 3 percent employer contribution and 1 percent employee contribution. Aware of the adverse effects on labor and production costs, the government has kept the payroll tax for health low compared to other countries and has agreed to reduce the payroll taxes for other programs by 10 percentage point. In addition to the revenue from the payroll tax, central budget allocations for health as well as revenues from, privatization, licensing fees, and interest income will go to the newly created State Health Fund (SHF). The SHF will act as a financial intermediary and reimburse both public and private health care providers for a basic package of preventive and essential clinical health care services included in the State Health Program. The SHF will be administratively independent from the Ministry of Health and governed by a Board which includes the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Health. A law passed in February, 1996 gave responsibility for managing the assets of the Fund to the Treasury. In addition, municipalities are obligated to provide a package of services under the Municipal Health Program. With these additional sources of revenues, public sector health spending is projected to reach 6.0% of total public sector expenditure in 1995 and 8.0% in 1996. Health care services not included in the State Health Program or the Municipal Health Program will be paid for out-of- pocket by consumers. (Annex C.6 provides a detailed description of the State Health Fund and the health care financing reform)
 - 4 - C. Key Sector Issues 1.13. The health care system has already started a dynamic transition from centralized to decentralized administration and financing, diversifying between public and private providers in a new competitive environment. As it continues to reform the health care system, the Government will need to address the following issues: (a) a deterioration in the health status of the population; (b) inefficient use of inadequate health service inputs; (c) poor quality of health care services; (d) inadequate access and coverage of health services; and (e) a collapse of government revenues. Deteriorating Health Status 1.14. Deteriorating maternal and child health. During the last five years, the health of women and children has deteriorated. The IMR has risen 13%, reaching an official rate of 21.4 (adjusted WHO definition) in 1993. Two-fifths of infant deaths occurred in the first seven days after birth. Out of these, 80% occurred in the first three days, suggesting the need for improved perinatal and neonatal care. Experts estimate that 57 % of child deaths from diarrheal diseases could be avoided through better management of medical supplies and health services. The maternal mortality rate (MMR) was estimated to be 39 per 100,000 births from 1990-93, and is expected to increase due to a recent rise in unsupervised home deliveries. The number of abortions in 1994 was estimated to be between 40,000 - 45,000, almost equaling the number of live births (51,000). 1.15. Increase in communicable diseases. The country's deteriorating socio-economic conditions, sizable displaced population, and collapsing health delivery system along with an increase in drug-resistant strains of microbes, have contributed to a marked increase in communicable diseases. Immunization of children almost completely ceased in 1992 leading to: (i) almost 300 cases and 42 deaths from diphtheria since October 1993; (ii) a 3.5 fold increase in the incidence of measles in 1993; and (iii) an increase in the incidence of pertussis. Acute respiratory infections (ARI) now account for 43 % of child mortality under 1 year of age. Increasing rates of drug abuse amongst young adults has lead to an increase in the incidence of Hepatitis-B in the 15-35 year age group. Recent trends also show a sharp increase in tuberculosis (TB) morbidity and mortality. The TB mortality rate is now 90% higher than any country in Western Europe. TB- associated meningitis, an indicator of the lack of early detection and effective treatment of tuberculosis, has increased from 10 cases in 1990 to 32 cases in 1993. The incidence of sexually transmitted diseases has also increased over the last three years. The incidence of syphilis, for example, increased 100% between 1993 and 1994. By January 1, 1995, 18 HIV-positive individuals were registered. 1.16. The hidden pattern of non-communicable diseases. Adult male mortality has become an increasing health problem. Although cancer rates are about 25% lower than and respiratory disease almost equal to the EU average, deaths due to cardio-vascular diseases (CVD) are higher than in Westem Europe. Cardio-vascular diseases accounted for 72% of total mortality in 1993. Over the last five years, deaths due to cardio-vascular diseases seem to have increased by 35%, and the overall age-adjusted mortality has risen by 18%, suggesting a continuing decline in the average life expectancy. Likely contributors to the apparent increase in cardio-vascular mortality are: the socio-economic crisis, the deterioration of health services, a lack of drugs, and less rigorous death registration practices. Furthermore, high rates of smoking and alcohol consumption are significant factors of morbidity and mortality (at least 50 percent of males over the age of 18 smoke) and partly explain the sharp increase in I ung cancer for men and breast cancer for women. The health determinants and health status of the Georgian population are described in more detail in Annex B.
 -5- Inefficiency 1.17. Like all countries of the Former Soviet Union, the health system in Georgia has been insensitive to the principles of both allocative and technical efficiency. Allocatively, Georgia has over-invested in curative health services at the expense of health promotion and prevention. Most of the resources have gone to hospitals which are overstaffed with specialized physicians. In addition to poor allocative decisions, the system has been plagued by technical inefficiency. The chronic under-financing of recurrent expenditures for drugs, fuel, and maintenance reduce productivity. Inefficiencies are further exacerbated by the excess supply of hospital beds and obsolete technology, generating low occupancy rates and long average length of stay. Perhaps most importantly, the system has been greatly constrained by a lack of management skills. 1.18. Allocative efficiency. The system is biased toward in-patient care, with a poorly developed capacity for public health programs. The health protection service, known as the Sanitary-Epidemiological (San-Epid) Service, is a strictly vertical organization oriented towards control of communicable diseases. Health professionals lack training in modem public health programs such as non-communicable disease prevention, immunization, respiratory and infectious diseases management, family planning, prenatal and neonatal care and emergency obstetrics. Comprehensive and intersectoral strategies for health promotion do not exist. 1.19. Deterioration offaciliies and equipment. Over half of the health care facilities were built before 1940. New facilities were readily financed to replace those that were deteriorating rather than maintaining the latter. In 1988, for example, 115 facilities were under construction, most of which remain unfinished today. Groundwater level changes have led to noticeable damage in buildings, including stability problems and cracks in structural components, walls and floors. Low quality materials and the absence of routine maintenance are responsible for falling ceilings, damaged walls, floors, and doors, and open window frames. In many buildings, roofs need immediate repair to avoid pennanent damage caused by leaks. The 1987 earthquake further contributed to the damage of health care facilities as have the recent civil wars, which not only damaged health care infrastructure, but also left many homeless refugees seeking shelter inside health facilities. 1.20. The existing medical equipment, mostly from Former Soviet Union and Eastern European countries, is outmoded and does not comply with modem safety standards, resulting in significant inefficiencies. Few spare parts and frequent power surges have led to a high proportion of non-functioning equipment, accompanied by a shortage of disposable items for diagnostic equipment (chemical reagents, X-ray films, and ECG paper). Inadequate disinfection and sterilization of medical and surgical materials is endemic. Ineffective boilers and dry heat sterilizers are still used in surgical and intensive care procedures, inhibiting infection control. Annex C.4 provides more background on the health care infrastructure and medical equipment in Georgia. 1.21. Misuse of health human resources. Georgia has more than 120,000 persons working in the health sector. The density of physicians is one of the highest in the world: 1 physician per 197 inhabitants, compared to an OECD average of 1:435. The large number of doctors is the result of Georgia's traditional esteem of medicine as a career and former Soviet Union policy emphasizing the number of physicians as a measure of achievement in the health sector. The number of nurses is also high relative to OECD countries, but they are poorly trained, unlicensed, and have low professional status and pay. Undertrained, underutilized and inadequately managed doctors and nurses greatly inhibit the efficiency and effectiveness of the Georgian health care system.
 - 6 - 1.22. During the Soviet period, one graduate and one post-graduate medical school provided all medical training in Georgia. After the break-up of the FSU, due to the increasing number of candidates and the refusal of other republics to admit foreign medical students, the Ministry of Education (MoE) granted authorization to 28 new private medical schools. There is no accreditation procedure for these schools, no quality standard for teaching, no career track for faculty, no reliable register for trainers and trainees, and no licensing or certification procedure for graduates. The total number of medical students in all schools is now around 2,500, about 10 times the requirement of the country. Similar problems are found in the post-graduate medical education system. There are no criteria for selection of persons to receive resident training, no standards to judge the quality of the training programs, and no process for certification of specialists once they have completed training. The educational process does not provide the knowledge and skills necessary to carry out competency-based and evidence-based care comparable to international standards. 1.23. The medical training system is characterized by early specialization and little focus on modern primary care, such as family practice and public health. Furthermore, concepts of modern public health are rarely covered. For example, the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) are unfamiliar to most health professionals. STDs are still managed in an outmoded separate delivery system of dermatological and venereal disease clinics. Education in contraceptive technology is also rare. As a result, family planning information and contraceptive methods for spacing pregnancies are not given in the immediate postpartum period. Abortion remains the dominant mode of family planning. Annex C.5 provides more background on health human resources. 1.24. Pharmaceuticals. The old system of state purchase and distribution of pharmaceuticals and supplies has collapsed. Currently, an estimated 75 % of pharmaceuticals is distributed through an unregulated private market. Humanitarian organizations import the rest. Pharmacies have spontaneously emerged both inside hospitals and other health facilities, as well as outside, in street kiosks. While the privatization of the pharmaceutical sector is a desirable direction toward which to move, without an adequate administrative and regulatory framework, the risk of overpriced drugs of inferior quality is high. Neither public nor private sector personnel have sufficient experience in pharmaceutical procurement and management. In addition, an adequate infrastructure for distribution and retail does not exist. Poor Quality 1.25. On all dimensions of quality of care -- structure, process, and outcome - Georgia has seen a marked decline. The physical structures and equipment are deteriorating. Hospital stocks are depleted and the quality of care received by patients is a function of their ability to obtain pharmaceuticals and medical supplies outside the hospital or clinic. In addition to the deficiencies in the physical infrastructure, medical professionals are poorly trained and their practices unregulated. Furthermore, the excess supply of physicians raises questions about whether the workload of physicians is sufficient to maintain their skills. In one major hospital, for example, the week's surgery schedule had only four operations for the staff of six surgeons. The increase in the number of private medical schools over the last three years raises additional concerns about the qualification of medical graduates. While outcome measures of quality are scarce in Georgia, the data which are available suggest that the decline in the structural variables described above are contributing to poorer health outcomes. The hospital mortality rate increased from 1. 1% of all patients treated in 1990 to 1.9% in 1993.
 - 7 - 1.26. Quality assurance in the former Soviet model of health care consisted of anmmal performance reviews, monitoring of patient complaints, and on-going monitoring of activities by hospital administrators. No formal accreditation process existed. Requirements for facilities were guided by norms and monitored by the Sanitary-Epidemiological Stations. These norms, oriented towards quantity rather than quality, were never consistently enforced. Adverse events, when reported, triggered punishment from authorities. Recent indicators suggest that even this limited level of quality assurance in Georgia is deteriorating. For example, under the former Soviet system, nearly all hospital mortalities were autopsied. A recent study found that the autopsy rate had dropped, ranging from 13% to 48% depending on the hospital. A decline in patient complaints over the last few years is likely to reflect a perception of unresponsiveness of the prior system rather than an increase in satisfaction. 1.27. The Ministry of Health has yet to identify quality assurance as a priority in its health care reform policy and a responsibility of the Government. Instead, it expects that a more competitive market will lead to improvements in quality as facilities of poorer quality will not survive. However, because patients are often unable to assess the quality of services, a Governmental role remains. Without a quality assurance system, human lives and the health of the population may be in considerable jeopardy. Annex C.3 provides more description on health care quality. Inadequate Coverage and Access 1.28. Historically, coverage of health care services has been quite high in Georgia. Although there were regional differences in the availability of medical services, access was adequate. The country's financial crisis, however, has greatly limited the availability of affordable, adequate quality health services. A 1994 national household survey found that 27% of the poor were unable to afford medical care. Physical access has been limited by a dramatic reduction in the availability of functioning ambulances and helicopters, necessary for serving mountainous areas in winter. These physical and financial limitations to access may explain the decline in utilization rates for hospitalization and outpatient visits over the last three years. Sustainable Health Care Financing 1.29. While Georgia was part of the Soviet Union, the health sector was under-funded, receiving from 2.8 to 4.1 % of GDP. The situation grew worse with the collapse of the economy. In 1994, public expenditures on health fell to 0.3% of GDP and 1.3% of public sector expenditures. Annual public expenditures on health averaged less than US$1 per person in 1994, less than 10% of 1990 expenditure levels in real terms. The fall in real expenditures was accompanied by a shift in the line item composition of expenditures. The rising costs of heating oil and other hard currency supplies crowded out spending on wages and maintenance in an increasingly limited budget. In 1990, wages and supplements were 52% of total expenditures. By 1993, they had fallen to 39% and in 1994 to 32% of the totals. Current real wages in health are equivalent only to a few loaves of bread per month. 1.30. Health care was primarily financed from the government budget although private payments to physicians have been an accepted, if illegal and undocumented, practice for many years. Over the last three years, however, revenue sources for the health sector have changed dramatically. The private sector has become the major source of revenues, providing possibly as much as 75 % of the total sector from 1991 to 1994. Public provision of services essentially ceased. In 1995, however, with the introduction of a new health reform program and an increased
 - 8 - central budget allocation to health, public expenditures increased. Per capita expenditures are expected to almost reach US$4 in 1995 and US$9 in 1996. As a percent of total public spending, health expenditures increased from 1.3% in 1994 to 6.0% in 1995 and are projected to increase further to 8.0% in 1996. The Government intends to concentrate available funds on those services which are public goods and the most cost-effective. This "basic package" of public health and essential clinical services includes immunization, prevention of socially dangerous diseases, maternal and child health services (including prenatal care and deliveries), treatment of tuberculous, inpatient psychiatric care, and provision of drugs for terminally ill patients. Consumers will pay out-of-pocket for services not included in the basic package, with exemptions for the poorest. While no private insurance exists today in Georgia, the Governments long term strategy is to develop compulsory insurance through SHF and allow voluntary insurance schemes regulated by the State, to cover services not covered by the SHF. While this increase in public spending is a signal of stronger government commitment to the health sector, it is considerably less than the US$22 per capita the 1993 World Development Report estimated is necessary to offer a package of public health and essential clinical services in a middle-income country. 1.31. Key issues the government faces with the new health care financing reforms are: (i) assuring the financial sustainability of the State Health Fund; (ii) developing an efficient provider reimbursement system; and (iii) guaranteeing affordable health services for the poorest. (These issues are discussed in greater detail in Annex C.6) 1.32. Financial sustainability of the State Health Fund. Currently, government projections for expenditures for the State Health Fund are 42.6 million lari for 1996, exceeding revenue projections by approximately 11 million lari. (Table 1.1) In addition to the concerns about the sustainability of central budget financing (approximately 50% of the Fund), the ability of the Government to collect the tax revenues earmarked for the Fund (approximately 20% of the Fund) and the projected degree of privatization (which is an unsustainable source of financing in any case), a further consideration is the projected volume of services and unit costs. The Government estimates of expenditures are based on current utilization patterns and do not consider latent demand that is suppressed by unaffordability or poor quality of services. If the Government is unable to control utilization, the cost of the basic package will exceed projections and add to the projected deficit. 1.33. In the short run, the most likely sources to fill the financing gap of the Fund are: i) international donors and humanitarian agencies, who currently provide more than 7.5 million lari of vaccines and medical supplies per year and have pledged an additional 10.9 million lari for 1996 to continue their support to Georgia within the framework of the new reforms and ii) additional revenues from privatization, assuming the Government's estimates are approximately one-third of what they expect. The additional assistance from donors and humanitarian agencies would cover the projected 11 million lari financing gap of the SHF. In addition, the following factors will be essential in order to achieve a balance of projected revenues and expenditures for the Fund: i) strengthened collection of tax revenues; ii) continued support from the central budget; and iii) implementation of a monitoring and control system. The Government has already introduced a new control system and technical assistance provided under other World Bank financed projects should strengthen tax collection.

Provider payment system. The reimbursement system designed by the MoH for the basic package combines two methods: capitation for some public health activities and a case based system for hospitals. For public health services covered by the basic package, such as immunization and maternal and child health services, providers will be paid an age-adjusted capitation fee ranging from US$1 to US$2 per capita. In the case-based methodology for hospitals, several diagnostic categories, which the Georgians refer to as "nosological" categories, were defined under the basic package, and for each one a standard level of health services was defined and priced. Hospitals are reimbursed by the State Health Fund for all patients who are admitted with diagnosis covered by the basic package. The unit prices include the quantity of medical consultations and tests for diagnostic purposes, the 'required' drugs and treatment medical acts and also the number of inpatient days for each category. 1.35. The reimbursement system for hospitalization, as currently designed, is clearly too complicated and administratively costly. To create and monitor a case-based reimbursement system, a significant amount of reliable information on costs and health services production is needed which is currently not available in Georgia. Furthermore, the possible perverse effects of such a reimbursement system are well described in the literature, including a strong incentive to increase artificially the utilization of more sophisticated resources, causing an increase in health care costs (exactly opposite to the intentions of the reimbursement system) and possible iatrogenic effects on patients. Difficulties in containing costs will only add to the difficulties Government faces in financing the very narrow scope of services included in the basic package. As a minimum, the Georgians should cap total expenditures for hospitalization under the basic package and lower the price paid per nosological category if volume rises faster than expected. 1.36. Affordabilit of servces for the poor. With two thirds of the population under the poverty line and approximately 800,000 in the most vulnerable groups (including more than 270,000 refugees), the Government is exploring ways to ensure that the very poor will have access to the essential health services which are not included in the basic benefits package. The two issues which remain unresolved are: (1) how to identify the poorest in an economy where a large part of the activity is informal and poverty is a widespread yet new social phenomena and (2) how to finance a subsidized program to support access to basic health services by the poor when public financial
 - 10- resources are extremely scarce and institutional capabilities are very weak. By the end of 1996, with technical assistance provided under the Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) and additional analytical work completed as part of the poverty assessment, a new program for social assistance will be established. 1.37. In the short-term, the Government first chose to address the needs of the poor by designating Tbilisi City Hospital #9 and several other specialty hospitals in Tbilisi to serve the needs of these groups. A total of 275 beds were designated to treat the most vulnerable groups free of charge: single unemployed mothers with three or more children, single pensioners with pensions below US$2 per month and single invalids. Other institutions, like the Veteran's Hospital, were financed by the State to continue providing care to their clients. Beginning in February, 1996, the Government revised its program by providing vouchers to the same target groups and allowing them to select their own provider. D. Government Reform Strategy 1.38. The objective of Georgian health policy is to improve the health of the entire population. The Government clearly recognizes both the need for reform and the opportunities for radical change presented by the current situation. Since 1992, the Government has progressively articulated, approved by legislative action or regulation and begun to implement a comprehensive reform which is described in detail in its Statement of Development Objectives (Annex A). The reforms will: a) concentrate scarce public resources on a basic package of public health (immunization, healthy children and safe motherhood, prevention of socially dangerous diseases, epidemiological surveillance, and health promotion) and essential clinical services (deliveries, treatment of children under the age of 14, treatment of TB, inpatient psychiatric care, provision of drugs for terminally ill patients, and emergency services). The scope of the package would be expanded as the economy improves. Services outside of the package, such as outpatient visits and non-emergency surgery, would be provided on a fee-for-service basis, with exemptions made for the most vulnerable groups; b) reduce the size and improve the quality of health sector personnel by: (i) removing physicians and other personnel from the government payroll, allowing competition to rationalize the number in the sector; (ii) limiting entry to medical schools; and (iii) instituting a licensing exam for currently practicing as well as recently graduated physicians. c) reduce the number and improve the quality and efficiency of health care facilities by: (i) privatizing most facilities and granting management autonomy to those that Temain in the public sector; creating a mixed, potentially competitive public/private market for patient services; (ii) reimbursing facilities for services delivered rather than by the number of beds and other norms; (iii) accrediting and licensing all health facilities; and (iv) introducing preventive maintenance of facilities and equipment, and upgrading service quality and management; d) separate provision of health care services from their financing. Health services will be provided mostly by the private sector, with a limited number of facilities in the public
 - 11 - sector. A new agency, the State Health Fund, was established in August 1995 and serves as a financial intermediary, receiving funds from the central budget and a 4 % payroll tax (3 % paid by employers and 1 % by employees) and reimbursing providers for services included in the basic package. Municipalities are required to cover health care services for emergency cases such as heart attacks, appendicitis, etc. In the short- term, municipalities are also required to provide subsidies to facilities in their jurisdiction to offset the costs of their utilities. e) limit the Ministry of Health's role to one of formulating policy, strategic planning, monitoring and regulation, and quality assurance; f) develop human resources to support the reform in areas such as modem public health, family practice, health services administration, and management.  - 12 - F. Lessons Learned from Past Operations 1.40. The World Bank's experience in Georgia dates only from FY94. An Institution Building IDA Credit of US$10.1 million equivalent was approved on July 5, 1994. A Municipal Infrastructure Rehabilitation Credit of US$18 million equivalent was approved on November 8, 1994. A Rehabilitation Credit of US$75 million equivalent was approved on March 30, 1995. This is the first credit operation for the health sector. Valuable lessons have been drawn from similar Bank projects in other countries -- particularly in Eastern Europe, Central Asia and Estonia -- as well as from the experience of other donors. The most frequently encountered problems that would be relevant to this operation include slow start-up of sector reforms, insufficient financial commitment to the health sector, political instability and frequent changes in ministerial high-level staff, inadequate institutional base of the health sector, initial weak project implementation capacity, and resistance to accept external technical assistance. Project preparation and design addressed these issues as follows: (i) the health sector is one of the leaders in reforming the economy: beginning in December 1994, strategic pieces of health reform legislation have been prepared, approved by parliament and the Head of State, and implemented; (ii) the Appraisal Mission confirmed an increase of public funding for health for 1995, raising average per capita expenditure from less than US$1 to almost US$4 between 1994 and 1995; (iii) an experienced and committed team remained mostly unchanged in the MoH after the November 6, 1995 elections; (iv) starting in early 1995, the MoH began a reorganization which included the creation of the State and Regional Health Funds, the Department of Public Health (with regional branches), the National Health Care Management Center, the Department of Pharmaceuticals and Pharmacy Industry, and the State Agency for Quality Assurance and reform of the existing Sanitary-Epidemiological, Medical Care and Maternal-and-Child Care Departments; (v) a PPF for US$500,000 was signed on August 25, 1995, allowing for a strong government role in project preparation and implementation by establishing a Project Coordination Unit inside the MoH before pre-appraisal and providing training in Bank procedures; finally, (vi) the Government has been very amenable to foreign technical assistance during project preparation and plans to use US$1.8 million of the Credit in order to continue to finance foreign technical assistance. G. Rationale for Bank Involvement 1.41. This project is consistent with the limited country assistance strategy, as discussed by the Board of Directors during presentation of the Rehabilitation Credit in March, 1995. Specifically, the strategy in Georgia is to help reverse the economic declines of the past few years and to assist the transition to a market economy. With a particular focus on promoting private sector development and redefining the role and improving the efficiency of the public sector, IDA is supporting economy-wide and sector-specific reforms and investments to promote economic growth in the productive sectors and to rehabilitate and build new capacity in critical infrastructure sectors. The Association will also assist in strengthening public management and developing human resources and institutional capacities throughout the economy. Strengthening the social safety net and targeting scarce public resources to the provision of public goods and to fight against poverty are the major strategic objectives in the social sectors. The project fully complies with this strategy.
 - 13 - II. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives 2.1. The proposed project would support the health sector reform efforts the Government has initiated and would aim to improve the health of the Georgian population. The project's specific objectives are to: a) reorient the health system towards cost-effective public health interventions like preventive and primary health care, assuring, in particular, better quality care for women and children, and focusing the MoH's activities on regulation of public and private providers; b) rehabilitate selected facilities and equipment that were down-sized and dedicated to cost-effective provision of maternal, perinatal, and pediatric care; c) develop human resources to support health reform, through continuing education for public health doctors, family practitioners, nurses, health administrators, and other personnel; and d) support the development of an independent health fund with regional branches, in order to finance a package of basic clinical services in a cost-effective and equitable manner. B. Project Description 2.2. Each component of the proposed Project is defined around a core policy agenda, described in detail in the Government's Statement of Development Objectives issued by the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Finance (SDO/Annex A). In the short-term, the project will focus on ending the deterioration of basic preventive and maternal and child care services and on separating financing from the provision of health care. In the medium-term, the project will: (a) reorient the MoH from direct management to regulatory, planning and quality assurance functions, (b) improve health promotion programs, (c) demonstrate how to rehabilitate selected health facilities, and (d) educate health managers. In the long-term, if the economy improves and reform is sustained, a second health project will be designed to consolidate health promotion activities and to rehabilitate and improve quality in a larger number of institutions. A Department of Public Health (DPH) was created in the Ministry of Health. The DPH is responsible for analysis and management of the epidemiological situation and the coordination of measures for disease prevention, reduction of disability and early mortality, and health promotion. These figures demonstrate a critical need to improve maternal, perinatal and neonatal care. A Project Implementation Plan has been developed including institutional and individual implementation responsibilities, a timetable for implementation, and monitoring indicators and policy-related benchmarks (Annex E). Two sets of indicators have been defined: process indicators (or input and output indicators) to measure progress in project implementation and impact indicators (or outcome and impact indicators) to evaluate improvements in the health system and in the health status of the population. The most important process indicators (most to be measured annually) include: (i) the number and value of awards granted by the Health Promotion Fund; (ii) the number of health care institutions licensed; (iii) the number of health professionals licensed; (iv) the percentage of pregnant women completing four prenatal visits and having a full risk assessment; (v) the number of people trained in public health, family practice, nursing, and management by the Center for Continuing Education; and (vi) the number of health facilities that are privatized. The most important impact indicators, also to be measured annually, include: (i) the prevalence of smoking; (ii) the incidence and mortality rate from circulatory diseases; (iii) the incidence and mortality rate from traffic accident related injuries; (iv) the knowledge, attitudes, and practices of all health personnel working in maternal and child health; (v) perinatal and infant mortality rate; and (vi) total health expenditures by sources and expenditure category. The project will also promote the use of monitoring indicators throughout the country by requiring recipients of the health promotion grants to document the impact of their respective projects. In addition, key policy benchmarks have been identified in the Government's Statement of Development Objectives and these will be reviewed annually by the Association and the Government as part of project monitoring. Responsibility for project monitoring will fall principally to the PCT T, which would monitor project tasks as defined in the project implementation plan as well as key indicators to assess project progress and impact in relation to specific objectives. 3.4.  - 30 - IV. BENEFITS AND RISKS A. Benefits 4.1. Although it is difficult to quantify the monetary and non-monetary benefits of the proposed project, the benefits can be grouped into: (a) real per capita increases in health expenditures; (b) reductions in the burden of disease; and (c) efficiency and equity gains in the allocation and use of resources. The project's support of key institutional health reforms, training of health personnel, scaling down of facilities and down-sizing staff in hospitals and polyclinics, and major changes in health service financing would, in the short-term, increase efficiency in the delivery of health services and contain costs. In the medium-term, the emphasis on healthy children and safe motherhood, added to the imnproved quality of health personnel and clinical treatments, would lower infant and maternal mortality and morbidity, reducing the economic burden of disease. In the long- term, preventive measures and promotion of healthy lifestyles, will curb avoidable adult mortality due to causes related to tobacco and alcohol consumption, unhealthy diets and injuries, further reducing the economic burden of disease. Quantitative analysis of benefits 4.2. Using the approach recommended by the World Bank's 1993 World Development Report, lnvesting in Health, an analysis of three of the health promotion programs to be included in the proposed project (smoking, cardio-vascular disease, and traffic prevention) as well as the maternal and child health activities in Kutaisi was carried out as part of project preparation. The study had the following objectives: (a) to estimate the burden of disease in Georgia, studying its distribution by nosologies, age, and gender; (b) to measure the burden of disease associated in particular with the main preventable health problems and diseases that could be reduced by the prevention programs; (c) to estimate the present health care costs associated with those health problems and diseases; (d) to estimate potential health gains achievable through the interventions; and (e) to analyze the cost- effectiveness of the three preventive programs and the Kutaisi MCH program proposed under the project. Detail of the study are included in Annex D and summarized below. 4.3. The results of the "burden of disease" analysis, using the disability adjusted life year (DALYs) methodology, show that the two groups where the most DALYs are lost due to premature deaths are infants (population under one year of age) and individuals aged 60 to 64 years. These results are consistent with the project's strong emphasis on maternal and child health and disease prevention. Looking across diseases, the study found that cerebro-vascular disorders and ischemic diseases are the most important health problems in Georgia, followed by accidents for men and breast cancer for women. The prevention programs proposed under the project could save nearly 200,000 DALYs by the year 2005. This is almost half of the burden of the diseases targeted under the prevention programs. Each DALY saved will cost, on average, US$2.83. For each dollar spent on the three prevention programs, US$63 could be saved in treatment and indirect costs. Total, discounted savings in direct and indirect costs over nine years would be US$35.5 million. Over three- quarters of the savings would come from the cardio-vascular disease prevention program. 4.4. The MCH program in Kutaisi, which includes higher investment costs (refurbishment and equipping the Kutaisi Maternal and Pediatric Hospital) and benefits which are harder to quantify, would save an estimated 16,489 DALYs at an average cost of US$138 for each DALY. The total cost of refurbishing and equipping the 60 bed perinatal center in Kutaisi,
 - 31 - US$2.3 million, is less than the estimated US$5.9 million it would cost to build a new center. Although a cost-effectiveness analysis of the rehabilitation and maintenance of Tbilisi City Hospital #2 was not included in the study, least cost analysis confirmed that refurbishing and equipping the facility as proposed under the project would cost US$5.7 million compared to US$10.9 to construct a new 126 bed hospital with the same function. Qualitative analysis. 4.1. While the analysis above demonstrates that the net present value of some of the project's health promotion programs exceeds total project costs, in fact, most of the project's benefits are unquantifiable. The project's activities will produce the following benefits: a) separating provision from financing of health services through an independent Health Fund will create conditions for the privatization of hospitals, polyclinics, dental clinics, as well as for pharmaceutical imports and distribution, under effective and efficient government regulation; b) improving preventive public health and maternal and child care services, and focusing the Ministry of Health on strategic planning, monitoring and policy adjustment will modernize and strengthen public management; c) reducing the State's financing role to a basic package of curative medical services and targeting the poorest through exemptions from health care costs, will improve efficiency in the health sector spending, and will free resources for the reinforcement of the social safety net; d) developing self-management capacity in hospitals and paying staff according to services provided by income solely generated by the institutions will improve efficiency and develop institutional capacities through the public sector and the economy at large; e) rehabilitating health facilities selected for their specific role in the project, according to modern programming and architectural standards to improve service effectiveness, safety, quality and energy efficiency, will generate positive examples of down-sized remodeling of critically needed and badly maintained social infrastructures; f) developing health human resources through continuing education and training will develop participation, will enlarge the circle of reform-minded stakeholders and will create conditions for the future multiplication of the reform results. B. Risks 4.6. The Government faces substantial financial, political, and institutional risks in implementing both its ambitious health care reform program as well as the project. A more detailed discussion of these risks is included in Annex D. The main risks include: (a) the fmnancial sustainability of the health care reform; (b) the ability of the Government to contribute its part of project costs; (c) the Government's commitment to continuing with the health care reforms; (d) the difficulties involved in transforming a curative health system into one more focused on disease
 - 32 - prevention and health promotion; (e) the complexities attached to restructuring institutions and strengthening the management of the hospitals and the health insurance funds; and (f) the lack of experience of the Government in implementing Bank financed projects. Many of these risks are common to any health reform process. Meeting the challenge is essential for both the transition to a market economy and the modernization of a badly functioning health care system. These risks have been addressed as follows: a) In order to ensure continued Government financial commitment to the health sector, both the Health Project and the Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) have included minimum spending levels on health as a condition of lending. The SAC specifies that at least 7 % of public spending must go to health and that this amount should rise as revenues increase. The Government has provided assurances that it would not reduce the scope of service included in the basic benefits package and would provide to the Association quarterly financial statements of the fund. b) The MoH reform record for 1995 is an outstanding one: (i) creation of a basic package of services, (ii) purchaser-provider split with the implementation of the State Health Fund, (iii) self-management capacity conferred to hospitals reducing dependence on govermnent budget, and (iv) change in the municipal health funding rules from physical norms to a per capita allocation, among other decisions. This effort is worthy of continuation and support. c) A new focus on adult health and on modem health promotion strategies to prevent the high economic and social burden of avoidable deaths and disability is an essential step to reach health levels similar to those in Western European countries. d) The lack of administrative, accountant and managerial experience inherited by the health administration from former Soviet times is a handicap that needs to be overcome in any case. Doing that simultaneously with a decisive health reform will generate synergy to the whole process. e) The creation of a PCU by pre-appraisal is improving project ownership and familiarity with Bank procedures and will allow for a quick start-up. Moreover, design includes features to attenuate risks, such as ensuring continued technical guidance and training for strengthening organizations and management practices, a detailed midterm review by the end of the second year of the project, and such matters as procurement, disburse ments, accounting and auditing.

 Annex A Page 2 of 10 STATEMENT OF DEVELOPMENT OBJECTIVES Introduction This document states the health policy of the Government of Georgia. It lists the strategic objectives in the health sector, indicating the legislation already passed to support these objectives. Each of the strategic objectives is analyzed: the major initiatives currently underway are identified, the planned activities are indicated and benchmarks for policy action are listed and scheduled. Strategic Objectives 1. The central objective of the Georgian health policy is to improve the health of the entire population through the design and implementation of a primary care-based system which emphasizes health promotion, disease prevention, and health protection. Health policy should move beyond curative medical services if it is to meet the full needs of the citizenry. Health and health care services also ought to be viewed as an investment in the creation of human capital, through the production of specific services in a transitional economic environment. 2. Consistent with the Health For All strategy devised by the World Health Organization European Regional Office, Georgia is in a process of reconstructing a curative delivery system severely damaged by intense civil conflict that greatly affected the Georgian economy and the health sector. To rebuild the economy and restore macroeconomic stability and foster the resumption of growth, our Government has been implementing a comprehensive program of macroeconomic stabilization and structural reforms with the assistance of the IMF and the World Bank. The Government commitment encompasses the reform of the health sector, and legislation has been passed and is under implementation with the following strategic objectives: (a) concentrate scarce public resources in better preventive public health and healtlY promotion services, and decentralize the health system administration; (b) restore the capacity of essential services for children and women and improve their performnance and quality to attain European levels; (c) limit the Ministry of Health's role in prevision and instead, refocus it on strategic planning, monitoring, quality assurance and policy adjustment; (d) scale down facilities and staff, introduce preventive maintenance of facilities and equipment, and upgrade service quality and management; (e) develop health human resources on areas of key importance to support the reform such as modem public health, family practice, health services administration and financial management; (f) privatize dental clinics, polyclinics, pharmacies and several hospitals and increase the selfmanagement of those remaining in the public sector;
 Annex A Page 3 of 10 (g) guarantee a core set of curative medical services for the whole population (basic package of care), and finance the non-basic package of services through co-payments, exempting the poorest; (h) change the previous financing system to one based on Government funding for the public health service, an independent payroll-based health fiund for the basic package, municipal funding for emergency acute care and individual payments for the remaining services. Recent Legislation 3. An important set of new health sector legislation is composed of the following pieces: (a) The Decree 400, issued by the Head of State on December 23, 1994 and later ratified by the Parliament, contains the first statement of the health reforn. The Georgian health sector will change from a centrally directed system, financed almost entirely from government revenues, into a decentralized system with a basic program financed by a pay-roll tax, selected specific earmarked taxes and government and municipal subsides. The remaining curative services will be financed through the private sector. There will be a clear separation between the sources of finance, the management of finance and the provision of services. This is intended to create a competitive environment with incentives for greater efficiency in service provision. Hospitals and other providers have been given great latitude in staffing and the administration of services. The role of the national Ministry of Health is being greatly reduced to strategic planning, monitoring and policy adjustment, including licensing and accreditation, quality assurance and provider regulation. The management of the health service delivery will be decentralized and 12 regional health authorities will be created to administer the transaction of the health fund, and to carry out the responsibilities of the regulatory agency at the local level.  ANNEX B Page 1 of 13 HEALTH STATUS: KEY ISSUES AND HEALTH DETERMNINANTS A. Demography 1. The population of Georgia is currently about 5.4 million with an average density of 73 persons per km . Fifty-six percent of the population is urbanized and one third of the poulation lives in the four largest cities: Tbilisi (1,300,000), Kutaisi (230,000), Batumi (200,000) and Rustavi (180,000). Georgia is a heterogenous society, comprising ethinic Georgians (70% of the population in 1989); Armenians (8 %), Russians (6%) and Azeris (6%). Recent civil wars left almost 5 % of the population as refugees (270,000). 2. The population had been relatively unstable over the last decade. The civil wars and declining socio-economic status have resulted in emigration and a dramatic fall in fertility (from 89,000 births in 1989 to 64,000 in 1993) which, when accompanied by increasing mortality, have contributed to an overall decline in population since 1991. Although the Soviet Union had undergone the demographic transition, in Georgia the elderly (65 and older) made up only 9.6 percent of the population while children (under 16) were 24.5 percent. B. Health Status 3. Information on recent trends on health status is difficult to obtain. The statistics are neither reliable nor consistent. This is characterized by contradicting information about the same indicator obtained from different sources, and low levels and unrealistic decline in several health status indicators. For example, very low cancer mortality figures compared to other countries are a likely indication of registration and/or reporting problems. The same applies to accidents and poisonings. Information gaps make it difficult to evaluate the deterioration or improvement of health status, to plan and evaluate public health programs, estimate the costs of basic benefits package, etc. The following are likely to be the causes of unreliable and inconsistent information: (a) social and economic disruptions; (b) duplication of data collection and data processing; and (c) information was not used for decision-making. 4. From the available information, the health status of Georgia's people appeared to compare well with the rest of the countries of the FSU. There were significant improvements between 1950 and 1970. Infant mortality was greatly reduced, and preventable communicable diseases were rare. However, since mid 1970s, like elsewhere in the FSU, the health status stagnated and started to deteriorate in late 1980s. This dynamic is partly due to emerging economic difficulties, but also a result of failing to recognize new health problems, in particular deteriorating adult health. Socio- economic disruption and civil war associated with the disruption of the Soviet Union have only sped up the deterioration of health status. Old problems of communicable diseases have re-emerged, and combine now with new health challenges, aggravated by the society's complete inability to respond. 5. Liffp=tany at birth in 1990 was 76.1 years for women and 68.7 years for men. For both sexes, life expectancy was higher (except for Lithuania in the case of women) than in any other FSU republic. There are no data available on the recent dynamics in life expectancy. The recent rise in overall mortality and comparative data about recent trends in other FSU countries make it reasonable to
 ANNEX B Page 2 of 13 assume declining life expectancy in Georgia. I Main causes of death are cardio-vascular diseases, neoplasms, and deaths from external causes (Tables 14, Figure 1). 6. The following are the key issues related to health status which Georgia faces today: (i) a deterioration of maternal and child health; (ii) recent re-emergence and increase of communicable diseases such as tuberculosos, AIDS, and STDs; and (iii) a hidden pattern of non-communicable diseases including high and rising cardio-vascular mortality, neoplasms, and accidents and poisonings. Deteriorating maternal and child health. 7. Infant mortality is more than twice as high in Georgia than in high income countries. In 1994, the official figure was 17.8/1,000 live births. Adjusting this figure for the WHO definition of IMR, the estimate would be 21.4/1,000. Given the problems with the credibility of information, this figure can still be an underestimate. IMR improved remarkably over the last 20 years (38 percent), but remains still more than two times higher than higher income countries. The WHO target for IMR for Europe is 20/1,000. IMR showed a net increase of 13 percent during the last three years. (Table 5). 8. In 1992, the main causes of infant mortality were perinatal conditions (5.6/1,000 live births, 38 percent of infant deaths), respiratory diseases (2.8, 19 percent of infant deaths), and infectious diseases (1.8, 12 percent of infant deaths). Twenty-seven percent of infant deaths were classified under 'other and ill-defined' causes, suggesting poor diagnosis and registration practices, as well as that the main causes of death may be even more important than stated. Two-fifths of infant deaths occurred in the first seven days after birth, and from these, 80 percent occurred in the first three days. These statistics clearly indicate inadequate health services for the perinatal period (Tables 6 and 7). 9. IMR is higher in towns than in villages. Gori, Batumi and Caducei had an IMR respectively of 56, 35, and 24 in the period from 1991 to 1993. Reducing the rates in Gori and Caducei to the national average would reduce IMR at the national level by one-sixth. 10. Incidence of acute respiratory infections (ARI) and diarrheal diseases is very high, according to MoH data. Incidence of diseases that are a target of the Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) (Table 4) have been increasing lately. Outbreaks of measles (180 cases) and diphtheria (+ 100) occured in Adjaria in 1994. There are cases of diphtheria all over the country and across all age groups, suggesting long-term breaks in immunization coverage. 11. In 1991, only 30 percent of newborns were breastfed until the sixth week of life, 22 percent at 3 months, and 3 percent at six months. There is malnutrition among under-five children, as well as micro- nutrient deficiencies. 12. Maternal mortality was 39 per 100,000 live-births in the period from 1990 to 1993 (Table 8). This indicator is 2.5 times higher than the WHO/EURO target (15/100,000 births), and 4 to 20 times higher than in high-income countries. As the absolute number of deaths is small (an average of 31 cases per year in the period 1990-93), it is difficult to interpret annual variations and to predict future ratios. However, maternal mortality is expected to further increase as a result of the rise in home 1 In Russia, male life expectancy declined from 63.5 years in 1991 to 62.0 years in 1992 attributed mainly to the increase in mortality among adult male population; the dynamics of female mortality have been less dramatic but many age-specific death rates rose by more than 50% during the same period.

The main causes of maternal death are hemorrhage (33 percent of all maternal deaths), infection (15 percent), and pulmonary embolism (12.5 percent). Abortion and its complications accounted for about 10 percent of maternal deaths in the period 1990-93, yet of the 22 deaths that occurred in 1993, none was due to this cause. The two major causes indicate again poor quality of health services. 14. The abortion ratio to live births varies with the source reporting, from 0.4 to 0.7 (for reference, in the UK it is 0.2), but both the Ministry of Health and the Zhordania Institute of Human Reproduction report declines in the number of abortions in the period from 1990 to 1994 (Table 9). Abortion by vacuum-aspiration (VA) and modern contraception are available in Tbilisi, at the Institute of Human Reproduction, but abortion by dilatation and curettage (D&C) is still four times more common in the country than abortion by VA. Illegal abortion (performed outside the health services) is reported to be unavailable. An abortion costs between 20,000 and 50,000 rubles (approximately US$7-17), while the insertion of an IUD costs 30,000 rubles (US$10). Replacement of D&C by VA may not constitute a problem, as soon as equipment is available. However, replacement of abortion by free, modern methods of contraception may face the opposition of physicians now charging fees for abortions. 15.
