See tables 10 andl 1. 17. Acute respiratory infections (AR) contribute 43% of child mortality rates under 1 year old. Diarrhoeal diseases are another main contributor to children's morbidity and mortality. Due to poor diagnostic capacity, about 33 % of cases remain unsolved. It is estimated that 57% of mortality from diarrhoeal diseases could be avoided by timely and adequate medical attention. 18. Tuberculosis (TB). Recent trends show a sharp increase in the incidence and prevalence of TB. The incidence was 42.6/100,000 in 1993, going up from 28.3/100,000 in 1990 (Table 12). Prevalence was 246.3/100,00 in 1993 compared to 140.7/100,000 in 1990. The mortality rate of 5.3/100,000 is considerably higher than that in West-European countries where in 1990, the highest rate of 2.8/100,000 was in Portugal.2 The existing Georgian rate is likely to be underestimated, as home 2 Source: Tubercle and Lung Disease (1994) 75, 400-416.
 ANNEX B Page 4 of 13 deaths may not have been reported and properly registered. Incidence of TB-associated meningitis, an indicator of the quality of early detection and effective treatment of tuberculosis, has increased from 10 cases in 1990 to 32 cases in 1993. Worsening socio-economic conditions, internal migration and the low standard of living conditions of displaced population (family TB), drug-resistant strains, and the collapse of the formal health care delivery system are cited as principal causes of the worsening TB situation. Immunization coverage of children that used to be in the range of 95-98% dropped to 78% in 1991, 0% in 1992, and 80% in 1993. The Mantoux test for early detection (formerly routine practice in the FSU) is no longer performed because of its high cost. 19. WHO is supporting Georgia in the control of the TB problem. Georgia has adopted a 5-point policy program proposed by the WHO consisting of the following components: (1) Government's conmmitment to national TB program; (2) passive case detection; (3) standardized definitions of TB cases for treatment options; (4) system of regular drug-supply; and, (5) standardized recording and registration procedures. 20. Sexually-transmitted diseases (STDs). Incidence of sexually-transmitted diseases (STDs) has been increasing lately, with Georgia having the highest incidence of syphilis (13.4 per 100,000 population in 1992) among the republics of the former Soviet Union. It is estimated that the incidence of syphilis in 1994 was 1,800 cases, an increase of 100% from 1993. The incidence of other STDs (gonorrhea, chlamydiosis, mycoplasmosis) show an increasing trend over the past 3 years. Worsening socio-economic conditions have created an increase in skin diseases (scabies and mycoses). 21. AIDS. By January 1, 1995, 18 HIV-positive individuals were registered. AIDS has been diagnosed in 4 cases, 2 of whom have died from AIDS-related diseases.3 22. Other. During one week in November-December 1994, there was an outbreak of 100 cases of botulism. The source was imported smoked fish from Armenia. This outbreak reflects relaxed regulation for food markets. An increase has been observed in the incidence of Hepatitis-B in the population age group 15-35 years old. This increase is being attributed to increase in drug-abuse. An estimated 200,000- 250,000 people use drugs. A survey performed by the national AIDS center estimates that 72 % of intravenous drug users occasionally/regularly use non-sterilized needles.4 Hidden Pattern of Non-Communicable Diseases 23. Cardio-vascular mortality is considerably higher than in developed Western countries but less than in other FSU republics (see table 4). Cardio-vascular diseases (CVD) accounted for 72 % of total mortality in 1993, represented by an age-adjusted mortality rate of 730 per 100,000 population. Cardio- vascular mortality is up from 65% of total mortality, or 544.2/100,000 in 1990. The MoH has questioned the reliability of official figures citing the problems associated with reporting (validity of death certificates). Nevertheless, the trend correlates very well with similar dynamics in Russia where cardio- vascular mortality increased from 617.4 to 768.9 per 100,000 between 1990 and 1993. Socio-economic crisis, deterioration of health services, lack of drugs and related high out-of-pocket costs are likely contributors to the recent increase in this mortality rate, in particular affecting the system's ability to cope with chronic cardio-vascular diseases and responses to acute illness episodes. 3 Source: National AIDS Prevention and Control Programme 4 Source: National AIDS Prevention and Control Programme
 AN'NEXB Page 5 of 13 24. Neoplasms. The official statistics appear to be unreliable and inconsistent, reflecting declining official cancer mortality rates. Lung cancer for men and breast cancer for women have sharply increased during the last two decades. Smoking and high concentration of carcinogenic agents in many mills and factories in Georgia are likely factors in oncogenesis.5 A perceived problem related to female reproductive system cancers in Georgia can be attributed to insufficient secondary prevention (lack of screening, early detection, and effective primary treatment). See tables 13 and 14, Figure 3. 25. Accidents and Poisonings. The official mortality data from accidents and poisonings are likely to be underestimated. Given the traffic patterns and the lack of enforcement of safety standard procedures, the resulting mortality and disability have to be close to the magnitude of other FSU countries (Table 11). Reporting and registration problems may contribute to the underestimation for two reasons: (i) mortality from traumatism is registered according to anatomical location, not by cause; and (ii) there is no link between the Ministry of Interior's register of traffic accidents and the MoH information on related morbidity and hospital and clinic admissions. 26. Psychiatric Morbidity. Incidence and prevalence of psycho-somnatic diseases have been stable: in 1993, there were 15,208 cases of schizophrenia and 8,632 cases of endogenous psychotic conditions. New problems in psychiatric morbidity are post-traumatic stress syndrome and neurotic disturbances, prompted by the worsening socio-economic situation and wars. The exact figures are not known because professional attention is being offered anonymously, because of cultural reasons and considerable internal migration of population. C. Health Determinants 27. Preker and Feachem6 suggest that the health gap between Central and Eastern European countries and Western countries may be partly due to lifestyle risk factors, and partly to differences in wealth and associated socio-economic factors, environmental pollution and occupational risks, and deficiencies in the preventive and curative health care services. The mortality gap between Georgia and high-income countries may steeply increase in the near future, due to aggravation of all mentioned factors. 28. Socio-econonic status. GNP per capita decreased 48 percent from 1991 to 1992, with 85 percent of families living under the Georgian poverty line in 1993, according to the Socio-Economical Infonnation Committee. In 1993, the average monthly salary was US$ 0.66. There is evidence, today, that many poor people do not have access to health services. High out-of-pocket costs of health services and drugs discourage people from using health services. The 270,000 thousand refugees are a particularly disadvantaged social group. Almost three-quarters of the displaced population have no income. Famnilies suffer from stress, poor living conditions in temporary housing, and organic diseases like family tuberculosis and parasites are common. Access barriers to health services (informal fees) have deferred many from seeking medical attention for their health problems. 29. Extended family plays an important part in Georgian society, and has proved to be one of the coping mechanisms with harsh-socio economic realities. This is one of the reasons why symptoms of S Source: National Cancer Control Programme. Oncology Research Institute. 6 Source: A.S. Preker and R. Feachem, 'Searching for the Silver Bullet: Market Mechanisms in the Health Sector in Central and Eastern Europe," presented during the Conference on Health Care Reform Strategies in Central Europe, Prague, November 10-12, 1993.
 ANNEX B Page 6 of 13 social febrility like alcoholism, juvenile crime, divorce, suicide and self-inflicted injury have occurred in much lesser scale than elsewhere in the FSU countries during recent socio-economic decline. 30. Environment. There is little information on environmental impact on health in Georgia. The country suffered from some fall-out of the Chemobyl disaster, and this has been blamed for significant increases in the incidence of pregnancy anemia, diseases of the endocrine system, diabetes mellitus, blood diseases and malignant tumors. No evidence has been produced to substantiate these claims. Tbilisi has a serious nitrogen dioxide, sulfur anhydride, lead and cadmium air-pollution. The collapse of public services has resulted in uncollected garbage and compromised water and sewage systems which pose a potential health hazard for the population. 31. In the past, drinking water was widely accessible. In 1990, 6 percent of water samples failed to meet chemical standards, and 16 percent failed biological standards. Since then, the situation has worsened, mainly because of poor maintenance and lack of electricity to operate pumps. Western Georgia appears to be the most affected region. Reduced access to continuous and safe water has been partly responsible for increased incidence of water born diseases, including diarrhea, dysentery, hepatitis A, and other infections associated with lack of hygiene, such as scabies. 32. Nutrition. The diet during the FSU era was rich in sugars and starches. About one-third of population was reported to be overweight. Since 1991, a decline in quality and quantity of Georgian diet has been observed. Consumption of bread, potatoes and oil has remained almost constant in absolute terms, whereas consumption of animal protein and dairy products has declined sharply. In 1993, daily consumption of total and especially animal proteins was below recommended standards (57 g of total protein compared to 88 g standard, and 9 g of animal protein compared to a standard of 46 g). 33. Micro-nutrients. About 1.5 million people live in mountainous areas suffering from endemic iodine deficiency. No complete data exist on the incidence of iron deficiency disorders. Small-scale studies by the State Medical University suggest that up to 60 percent of children in endemic areas have pathological conditions of various degrees. Economic hardships do not allow the import of iodized salt from Armenia nor iodine tablets from Russia. 34. Lifestyle choices. There are no recent data about cigarette consumption, but it is assumed that this practice is highly prevalent among men (60-80 percent), and increasing among women. In the 1960s, 78.5% males and 7.5% females smoked; in the 1980s the respective figures were 68-72% for males and 8-16% for females.7. Georgians are smoking United States brands, that are aggressively marketed both in urban and rural areas. It is also assumed that drug addiction is increasing, specially among young people. 35. Health system. The ability of the health care system to respond to the country's worsening health situation has been seriously compromised. The access to health services is not universal, but depends on the ability to pay informal fees for medical services, drugs and other essential supplies. Lack of resources and inadequate management practices have resulted in deteriorated buildings and non-functioning equipment. Standards for professional expertise are lacking, and patients' perception of the quality of care received is low. The health care system has been oriented towards curative care, infrastructure and professional expertise for cost-effective primary care interventions is lacking. More detailed analysis of the health care system is presented in another annex. 7 Source: Oncology Research Institute and Institute of Cardiology data.
 ANNEX B Page 7 of 13 D. Conclusions 36. There appears no room for the health system to contribute significantly to the improvement of the health status of the Georgian population. This should be done by ensuring access to basic health services for all social groups, reorienting the system towards cost-effective primary care interventions, increasing efficiency of the system through proper incentives and improved management practices, and ensuring standard quality for health care provision in Georgia. 37. In order to design, implement and evaluate interventions intended for the improvement of health status in Georgia, several actions need to be taken. There is a need to consolidate and improve data collection, processing and utilization functions; capacity to control non-communicable disease needs to be enhanced allowing better understanding of morbidity and mortality patterns and link them to risk factors. This would provide adequate estimates of the burden of disease in society, and help to design effective health promotion programs. 38. The recently-established National Health Management Center (NHMC) has an important objective to consolidate and improve the national health information system. This effort is intended to coordinate the activities of the following institutes: Institute of Informatics, Institute of Medical Information and National Medical Library, Department of Statistics in the MoH, and the Sanitary-Epidemiology System.  Annex C. 1 Page 1 of 6 HEALTH PROMOTION AND DISEASE PREVENTION' A. Objectives 1. Worsening adult health is a major factor in the decline of the health status of the population of Georgia. Current trends in lifestyles and changes in social and physical environment will contribute to the increase of health problems and deaths markedly by the year 2000 if vigorous measures in promoting and protecting health are not applied. More than 430,000 disability adjusted life years (DALYs) are lost per year to ischemic heart disease, lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cerebro-vascular disorders, and traffic accidents. 2. There is an urgent need to establish health promotion and disease prevention programs. Community-based inter-sectoral and vertical program activities to reduce health risks and to create availability of healthy choices and environment are called for. Special attention should be paid to school and youth programs. Estimated savings from the planned health promotion and disease prevention programs are nearly 200,000 DALYs at the cost of US$ 2.83 per DALY saved.2 3. The health promotion and disease prevention sub-component seeks to: (1) establish sustainable conditions for health promotion in Georgia, this will include policy development and creation of appropriate structures for administration, funding, program activities, research and evaluation; and (2) launch immediately programs in priority areas including reduction of tobacco consumption, cardiovascular disease prevention, traffic and occupational injury prevention, reduction of alcohol consumption and family planning. B. Supportive policies for health promotion 4. Long term and sustainable commitment. The Government of Georgia shares with its citizens the responsibility to promote and protect health and recognizes that the major benefits from health promotion will come from longer-term investments. Legislation is called for in many areas such as environmental control, food policy, and production and sales of harmful goods. In order to promote inter-sectoral coordination, a National Health Council should be formed, with representatives from all relevant ministries. In order to ensure sufficient allocation for health promotion activities and encourage innovative community initiatives, a Health Promotion Program (HPP) has been established. Government funding for the HPP will be mandatory and independent from political changes. Resources should be allocated on a rational basis to programs that address issues of greatest public health importance using strategies based on evidence. 5. Recognition of the social, economic and environmental detenninants of health. The Government of Georgia recognizes the impact of access to education, inequality of income, deficiencies in housing and dangers in the physical environment on health. National health goals and objectives will be analyzed and documented. A comprehensive health promotion strategy will be developed and adopted 1 The sub-component draws on the work of Dr. Matti Rajala, consultant, and his Georgian counterparts Drs. Ramaz Urushadze and Archil Kobaladze. 2 See Annex D for more details on the Burden of Disease and Cost-Effectiveness Analysis, by Costa and Gouveia.
 Annex C. I Page 2 of 6 involving actions directed not only to individuals, but also to the social and economic conditions that enable people to make health choices. This work will be coordinated by the MoH's Department of Public Health, and then discussed and approved by the National Health Council. Wide participation of all relevant sectors will be used to create, publish and disseminate A National Health Strategy document. The impact of different public policies on health should be systematically assessed and made explicit (e.g. taxation, housing, transportation). Analytical tools, such as an health impact assessment, will be developed. 6. The role of the Regional Health Departments is crucial in the development and coordination of health promotion activities. As the Government becomes increasingly decentralized, Districts may provide the best opportunity to develop and demonstrate practical models of health promotion. Considering the limited availability of resources and expertise, a step-wise model should be applied. Pilot projects in a number of regions and districts should be launched. Partnership with non- governmental organizations in policy development, program development and delivery will also be encouraged. C. Sub-Component Description Department of Public Health 7. A Department of Public Health (DPH) has been established at the Ministry of Health. The Department has responsibility for monitoring and analyzing the health status of the population (both communicable and non-communicable diseases), managing the epidemiological surveillance and rapid response systems, advising the Government on public health policy issues, coordinating inter-sectoral health programs through the National Health Council, coordinating regional public health offices, and coordinating and analyzing the impact of health promotion and disease prevention programs. A Division for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention (DHPDP) has been established in the new Department of Public Health to provide leadership for health promotion and disease prevention in Georgia. The DPH will also oversee the Center for Health Information and Statistics, Center for Disease Control, and a number of other research institutes. 8. The DPH will have the following functions and responsibilities. a. Comprehensive analysis of needs and resources. MoH, advised by DPH will prepare a national overview of health issues. The DHPDP analyzes the range of possible health promotion strategies, and assesses resources available in order to shape health promotion policies and develop priorities for action. b. National monitoring of health behaviour. For sound policy-making and assessment of health gains, systematic monitoring of health behaviour should be started. Planning and implementation will be DHPDP's responsibility. c. Policy analysis and development. DHPDP/DPH advises MoH to develop and propose new policies within the health system, and assess the health-impact of policies, and propose modifications when needed. d. Alliance building for health. DHPDP supports the development of partnerships for health strengthening policy development and health promotion action at all levels. A national multi-sectoral committee will be established to coordinate and
 Annex C. 1 Page 3 of 6 support health development. Special attention should be paid to youth and schools. e. Program support to serve regional and local activities. DHPDP will support regions, districts, community groups and practitioners either by the direct provision of financial (e.g. grants) and technical (e.g., information and consultations) resources, and by co-ordinating decentralized program implementation. f. Research and evaluation. Collection of information on the effectiveness of various health programs and strategies is essential to review work programs as well as making this information available. DHPDP will implement an ongoing evaluation of the program activities and will support research in this field. g. Human resources development. DPH and DHPDP will support education and training, and ensure access to information on best practice. They will also encourage rapid dissemination of practical experience. h. International relations. To ensure the exchange of knowledge and experience active international collaboration is needed. Georgia will participate in the work of WHO's European Committee for Health Promotion Development. DHPDP will assume national membership in the International Union for Health Promotion and Education. 9. Trained professionals at the national, regional and local levels are required to plan and implement health promotion programs. Foreign technical assistance in behavioral, political and social sciences and health economics will help to develop multi-disciplinary technical expertise in the DPH, where the first priority for training will be given. In the second phase, aided by the Center for Continuing Education, graduate, post-graduate and in-service training will be provided to professionals at the regional and local levels. Universities and health professional associations will also have a crucial role to play in health promotion. 10. Access to reliable epidemiological and health services data is required to monitor the health of the population and assess the progress of the various health promotion activities. In collaboration with the WHO, the project will support the creation of a health information system. The system will regularly monitor health status, health-related behaviours, and social and economic determinants of health, and issue annual reports to the MoH and the public. Priority Disease Prevention And Health Promotion Programs 11. In order to promote inter-sectoral collaboration and local initiatives in health promotion, a Health Promotion Program (HPP) has been established in Georgia as part of the Project. The Program will be financed by a mandatory allocation from the State Health Fund (1 % of annual income from the government budget, payroll tax, and tax on hazardous products) as well as by proceeds from the IDA credit. 12. Programs in cardio-vascular disease prevention, anti-smoking, injury prevention, and family planning will start imnmediately under the project. These program have the potential to save 200,000 DALYs by the year 2005. They are implementable, will produce measurable results, and will
 Annex C. I Page 4 of 6 provide health promotion with a high profile. Given the scarcity of resources, the programs will target areas with the potential for the greatest impact, such as schools. 13. Cardiovascular disease prevention. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) mortality is considerably higher than in Western Europe and North America, but lower than in other FSU republics. CVD mortality is by far the most important cause of death. Although the reliability of the available data is questionable, the trend is similar to Russia where CVD mortality increased from 617 to 769 per 100,000 between 1990 to 1993. In Georgia, CVD represented 72% of total mortality in 1993. Deterioration of the curative services may have contributed to the increase. In the long run, however, preventive measures will provide the only sustainable solution to the problem. Between 1996 and 1999, the project's health promotion and disease prevention programs target a 2% yearly reduction in incidence and mortality rates from ichaemic heart disease and 3% yearly reduction in incidence and mortality rated from cerebro-vascular diseases. 14. Smoking, high blood cholesterol, high blood pressure and excess body weight are the main risk-factors for high mortality and morbidity from circulatory diseases. These will be the areas for the public health intervention under the project. 15. National strategy for tobacco control. Tobacco smoking is the main risk factor for cardio-vascular disease. In Georgia, more than 50% of men smoke and rates amongst both men and women are increasing. As the markets in the industrialized western countries are shrinking, the trans- national tobacco companies have started to exploit FSU and CEE markets, further increasing the possibility someone will smoke. An effective tobacco control strategy will have the following components: (i) legislation restricting advertising and promotion of tobacco products, restricting sales to youngsters, and requiring warnings about the health effects of tobacco; (ii) economic policies which include progressive significant increases in sales tax on tobacco; (iii) "Smoke free" public policies, starting with the MoH, which emphasize that the right for smoke-free air is stronger than the right to smoke; (iv) health education in schools, targeting people before they start smoking; and (v) counselling and support for smokers who wish to stop. The project's target for the anti-smoking program is a 15% decrease in smoking prevalence by 1999. 16. Healthy nutrition. The Government needs to develop a national food policy which is consistent with acceptable nutritional concepts and ensures the nutritional quality of food. Such a policy should be developed by a multi-sectoral committee, comprising all Ministries whose policies affect production, distribution, and food consumption such as Agriculture, Education, and Health. Animal production policies should be assessed in order to ensure that existing incentives do not promote an excess of saturated fats. High priority should be given to the production and availability of foods which are low in fat, sugar, and salt. This may call for new legislation bearing on agriculture and food, to ensure that it is compatible with the prevention of CVD. The MoH and Ministry of Education should ensure that, as part of nutrition and health education for teachers and students, attention is paid to the prevention of diet related chronic diseases. In the future, the DPH should start a campaign to promote a healthy Georgian diet and monitor the nutritional intake of the population. 17. Promoting physical activity. Lack of physical activity is a major determinant of CVD and other chronic conditions such as osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, and obesity. Even moderately intense physical activities, such as walking and dancing, can be valuable in helping to reduce the risk of CVD and in preventing muscle wasting, which is the most common cause of disability in the elderly. DPH should start an awareness building campaign among health professionals as well as among the general public about the benefits of physical activity in its widest sense as a part of daily life. Children should be
 Annex C. 1 Page 5 of 6 encouraged in schools and during their leisure-time to enjoy a wide range of sports, games and other activities which they can continue after they have left school. 18. Multiple risk factor prevention activities. The risk factors for CVD are synergistic, with each extra risk factor multiplying the risk in a given individual. Structural, socio-economic, and psycho- social factors determine the opportunities people have for choosing a healthy lifestyle. Schools provide an important and effective arena for comprehensive health promotion efforts. Georgia should consider joining the WHO Healthy Schools project to link healthy nutrition, non-smoking and physical activity in the school. Health promotion activities in the workplace should be increased and improved by collaborating with the employers and employees to develop a workplace good-practice initiative. This should address work patterns, environment, and management culture as well as smoking, nutrition, and physical activity. The Government should also encourage its municipalities to join the WHO Healthy Cities initiative, which forges 'healthy alliances' between different agencies inside and outside the health sector. 19. Traffic and occupational injury prevention. Reliable data on injury epidemiology are scarce. It is estimated that traffic accidents cause approximately 2,000 deaths and 2,000-3,000 permanent disabilities per year. Occupational accidents contribute an additional 15,000 injuries each year. Given the lack of enforcement of traffic regulations and safety procedures as well as data from other FSU countries, these numbers very likely understate the magnitude of the problem. 20. To reduce mortality and injuries caused by accidents, cooperation between the police, schools, occupational safety and labour organizations should be developed. The existing traffic safety regulations should be reviewed in collaboration with the law-enforcement organizations in order to develop measures that are feasible and realistic for decreasing accidents leading to death and disability. In this context, the use of seat-belts, speed limits, drunk driving, and traffic arrangements may be relevant issues. Occupational safety regulations should also be reviewed and due actions taken. Contraceptive prevalence rates in Georgia are low, ranging from 2% to 25%, depending upon the source. Among women practicing birth control in 1992, 32% used pills, 18% IUDs, 19% condoms, 12% spermicides, and 15% "traditional methods". Elective abortion remains the primary means of birth control and the number of elective abortions is reportedly increasing due to shortages of pills, IUD's and condoms.  Annex C.2 Page I of 4 HEALTHY CHILDREN AND SAFE MOTHERHOOD A. Introduction 1. In the 1990s, fertility dramatically decreased in Georgia, while infant and maternal mortality have been rapidly increasing. The Georgia Health Project is designed to reduce infant and maternal mortality in the whole country, bringing the death rates to values closer to the WHO targets for the European region: fewer than 15 infant deaths per live births and 15 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. 2. The total number of births decreased from 89,000 in 1989 to approximately 64,000 in 1993. The crude birth rate dropped from 19.2 in 1970 to 17.0 in 1990, and 11.8 in 1993. This drop is occurring despite a stable abortion ratio (0.6-0.7 abortion per live birth), and a contraceptive prevalence rate that may be as low as 2%, or as high as 25%, according to different sources. 3. The infant mortality rate declined between 1960 and 1990 from 35.3 to 15.1 infant deaths per 1,000 live birth, but in 1993, the estimated IMR had risen by 13 percent, reaching 21.4 infant deaths/1,000 live births. However, in specialized reports, the IMR is estimated to be between 30-50 infant deaths/1,000 live births. Forty percent of all infant deaths occur in the first seven days after birth and an estimated four-fifths of these occur in the first three days of life. 4. The maternal mortality rate for the period 1990-1993 was approximately 39 deaths per 100,000 births. The major causes of maternal mortality are hemorrhage (38%), causes related to obstetric management (29%), abortion (14%), sepsis (9%), toxemia (3%), and other causes (7%). Both age of the mother and her parity are associated with a higher relative risk for maternal death. Women over 30 years of age account for 48 % of the deaths. Three-fourths of maternal deaths occur among multiparous women, with 34% occurring among women with greater than five pregnancies. B. Objectives 5. The project will carry out a set of integrated actions intended to reduce perinatal and maternal deaths in a situation of scarce resources. The sub-component Healthy Children and Safe Motherhood specifically aims to decrease infant and maternal mortality by 30% countrywide, and to decrease infant, perinatal and maternal mortality by 50% in Tbilisi and Kutaisi in the four years duration of the Project. Project activities in this area are expected to ensure public funding for some of the most cost-effective health interventions, to increase contraceptive coverage and decrease abortion, and to improve the quality of perinatal care. Activities with an impact on women's and infants' health will be carried out in the other components of the project, including Health System Reorientation, Rehabilitation and Maintenance of Health Facilities, and Development of Health Human Resources.

 Annex C.3 Page I of 5 REALIGNMENT OF THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH: QUALITY ASSURANCE, MONITORING AND REGULATION A. Objective 1. The objective of this sub-component is to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Health to monitor, regulate and assure the quality of health care services. The sub-component will: (a) license health professionals and create a data base of registered doctors and nurses; (b) register, license and inspect health care facilities to create a data base of physical resources and ensure quality standards; (c) support health care institutions willing to develop internal quality assurance programs; (d) reorganize the administrative structure of the Department of Pharmaceuticals and Pharmaceutical Industry, and support a quasi-governmental Agency for Drug Regulation and Quality Control which will have the responbility for registering, assuring the quality, inspecting, and providing information on pharmaceutical products. These activities will help to reduce the excess supply of doctors and hospital beds and ensure that providers, institutions, pharmaceuticals and related products meet adequate quality standards. B. Quality of Care 2. Georgia is in a state of economic crisis. The health care system is not capable of responding to the declining health status of the population because of a lack of resources, regulation and management. Consequently, the quality of health services is deteriorating rapidly. Quality of inputs -- pharmaceutical and medical supplies, buildings and technology, human resources, and financial resources -- is poor and declining. Data on the process and outcomes of health care are scarce, but preliminary findings point to problems in the appropriateness of care, which affect both the costs and the outcomes of medical interventions. 3. Input variables are often most important in low income countries. In middle income countries, which already have the required inputs, process variables become a priority. Georgia falls somewhere between these two categories: surplus inputs need to be optimized and their quality improved and processes need to be changed before better outcomes will be achieved. For countries with scarce resources, improving quality becomes especially critical in order to maximize health benefits with the given amount of resources. 4. Deteriorating Health Facilities. Georgia has an extensive network of poorly maintained health care facilities: 338 hospitals and 1,252 outpatient facilities in 1992. More than half of the facilities are over 50 years old. According to the Government's own estimates, 122 hospitals need significant repairs and renovations. Public resource allocation for maintenance and capital investmnent accounted for only 1.7% of public health care expenditures in 1992 and has continued to decline. 5. Poor diagnostic and therapeutic capabilities. Most of the diagnostic and therapeutic equipment is of Soviet or Eastern-European origin. It is poorly maintained and technologically out-of- date. In the past, public sector institutions had no incentives to maintain equipment because the central level decided when and how much equipment to buy. A visit to one of the three intensive coronary care
 Annex C.3 Page 2 of 5 units in Tbilisi (Municipal Hospital #1) revealed that 8 patients with acute heart conditions had to share a single functioning monitor. The unit was short of medicines and disposables, and unable to offer modern treatments such as thrombolytic therapy and central haemodynamics monitoring. Diagnostic capacity was impaired by a lack of paper for the electrocardiograph and batteries for the Holter monitoring device. Ambulatories providing primary health care at the local level also lack diagnostic and therapeutic capacity. 6. Quality of health professionals. Quality of health professionals in Georgia is poor for several reasons. First, an excess supply of physicians relative to other health professionals has downgraded the activities performed by doctors. Excess supply also results in a lower than optimal workload, important for maintaining adequate skill levels. Second, there are no training or practice standards. A diploma from a medical school does not guarantee a standard quality for health professionals. Professional organizations are weak, and do not exercise self-regulation. Relicensing of existing health professionals, and introducing standards for new graduates, is necessary to ensure the minimum standard of professional expertise in Georgia. Finally, low salaries and few opportunities for professional advancement contribute to low staff morale. 7. Phannaceuticals. The pharmaceutical sector is largely uncontrolled and unregulated by the Government. Administrative structures have been created for quality control and inspection, but are inefficient due to a lack of legislation, improper infrastructure, poor financing and management. Private kiosks selling pharmaceuticals are appearing everywhere. Between 1991and 1994, 1,500 licenses were issued and it is estimated that another 500 kiosks operate without licenses, not meeting standards of storage sale. Such an uncontrolled pharnaceutical market poses great health risks to the population. 8. Access to pharmaceuticals deteriorated after the collapse of the Soviet pharmaceuticals market and the Georgian economy. Although it is estimated that 90% of essential pharmaceuticals are available in the country, their distribution is uneven, quality is poor, and they are unaffordable for many. Limited raw materials and packaging have reduced the production of ex-tempore pharmaceuticals. Ready made pharmaceuticals are available but the choice is poor. One international NGO, UMCOR, estimates that 50% of the population cannot afford to pay for pharmaceuticals. Donations of pharmaceuticals have been vital for Georgia, and international assistance has been able to avoid the worst of the crisis. During forthcoming years, however, NGOs plan to gradually phase out their activities. There, it is critical to reform the pharmaceutical sector into a well-regulated, affordable and financially sustainable system. Process variables 9. Process variables which affect the quality of care include the organization and management of services, accessibility and continuity of care, and the appropriateness of care. In Georgia, a centralized health system is less responsive to local needs. Poor management has limited the ability of the Government and health insitutions to monitor and influence the quality of care, efficiently procure and distribute drugs, and adequately define standards for services and inputs. Current utilization of hospital services by the population is considerably lower now than three years ago. Annual outpatient visits have declined from 10.4 per capita in 1990 to 5.3 in 1993. Although current outpatient utilization indicators do not compare badly with international data, it is unknown whether the decrease in utilization represents unmet need. There is little evidence on the appropriateness of medical interventions in Georgia. No cost- effectiveness or small area variations studies exist. Standardization of medical procedures and guidelines
 Annex C.3 Page 3 of 5 for appropriate distribution of medical technologies are lacking. Options for intervention often lie out of reach of medical professionals. C. Government Strategy 10. The changes in organization and financing of the health system included in the Government's health care reform strategy will lead to improvements in the quality of care. Reduction of excess capacity should make the system more efficient; decentralization should make the system more responsive to local needs; introduction of a competitive market should increase the importance of quality to health care providers. The Government is also taking specific steps to improve the quality of the health services' inputs by establishing standards for health care providers and health professionals and regulating the pharmaceutical sector. But, limited progress and even possible decline in quality could occur if regulation of private health care market fails, clear accountability is missing and management skills are lacking. 11. Establishing standards for health care providers. As part of the Government's health care reform, a State Agency of Quality Assurance for Health Care Providers has been established. This Agency will be responsible for registering and licensing health care facilities, based on standards for physicial infrastructure, equipment and staffing.  Annex C. Page 1 of 6 REHABILITATION AND MAINTENANCE OF HEALTH FACILITIES AND EQUIPMENT A. Objective 1. The poor condition of health facilities and equipment in Georgia is an obstacle to the reform of the health system and improved delivery of medical care. The old system was plagued by a lack of experience in functional programming, architectural design, sound construction and preventive maintenance. These problems, combined with the 1987 earthquake and recent civil wars, have led to a deterioration of health facilities which is both inefficient and unsafe. Furthermore, a centralized administration and the lack of a reliable communication system have undermined the ability of the government to respond to deterioration of health services. This deterioration of the health care environment is most likely one of the reasons the health status of the population has worsened. The health services are less able to deal with complications; polyclinics have a diminished consulting capacity and hospitals show lower occupancy rates than before. Essentially, the delivery of services has collapsed. 2. This component would support the rehabilitation and maintenance of health facilities in Georgia by refurbishing three facilities in Tbilisi, Kutaisi, and Tsageri which will serve as centers of clinical excellence for the provision of perinatal health services; building capacity in the MoH's Building Technical Department (BTD) to set standards for the programming, design, and rehabilitation and construction of health facilities; building capacity of the Committee of Medical Technologies and Equipment (CMTE) to identify the needs, conduct technology assessment of, and procure medical equipment; and providing training for hospital programmers, architects, biomedical engineers, maintenance specialists and hospital staff on facilities design, construction, and equipment maintenance. B. Background 3. Decades of centralization have left users without a sense of control and ownership of the systems that should be serving them. The distance between the users and authorities has eliminated, at all levels, any incentives to administer and protect user-friendly, functional, cost-effective, and sustainable health facilities. Further obstacles include lack of experience in: (i) establishing building standards; (ii) programming spatial functions; (iii) designing architectural spaces in a cost-effective manner; (iv) planning and managing complex medical equipment; (v) practicing competitive procurement procedures that will result in the acquisition of economical, quality civil works and goods; and (iv) organizing, managing and financing effective maintenance systems to protect occupants, buildings and equipment. 4. Design. Health facilities are located in large, underutilized buildings planned under the standards of the former Soviet Union. The Eastem pattern of concentrating facilities in "large complexes" can also be found in Tbilisi and other large Georgian cities. Over-dimensioned areas of hospital departments mean additional costs for heating, lighting, maintenance, cleaning, and safety. Furthermore, poor use of space leads to increased circulation time for patients and staff. 5. Building Maintenance. About half of the facilities were built before 1940 with no further maintenance. Damages in building structures are the results of stability problems caused by
 Annex CA Page 2 of 6 earthquakes, ground water, mediocre material, and poor construction techniques: cracks can frequently be seen in structural components, walls and floors. Heavy deterioration of buildings and infrastructure is evident. Deteriorating building materials commonly seen include: leaky roofs, hanging gutters, broken drains, plaster falling from the ceilings, floor material peeling off, non-insulated windows, and broken sash and glass. The building systems are often unsafe or non-operational: blocked sanitary facilities, cracked heating pipes, exposed wiring, and fluorescent tubes destroyed by fluctuating current. 6. Equipment and supplies. The average age of essential medical equipment such as X-ray machines, laboratory and physiotherapeutic equipment, endoscopes, ventilators, intensive-care monitors, and surgical equipment is 8 to 15 years. The equipment no longer complies with modem technological and safety requirements. Sterilization in some surgical and intensive care units is done using boilers and dry hot sterilizers. Stocks of health care supplies are insufficient and shortages of spare parts, reagents, X- ray films, and ECG paper impair the functioning of 70% to 80% of the equipment. Oftentimes, patients must provide their own linen, food, drugs, medical supplies and transportation. Humanitarian aid, however, has contributed to acquisition of some modern equipment. C.  Annex C. S Page I of 4 HUMAN RESOURCES A. Introduction 1. Georgia has more than 120,000 persons working in the health sector. The density of physicians is one of the highest in the world: I physician per 197 inhabitants. There are approximately 30,000 practicing physicians compared to an estimated need of 10,000-12,000. The large number of doctors is the result of Georgia's traditional esteem of medicine as a career and former Soviet Union policy emphasizing the number of physicians as a measure of achievement in the health sector. The number of nurses is also high relative to OECD countries (70,000 nurses compared to a need of 40,000), but they are poorly trained, unlicensed and have low professional status and pay. The nursing education system was oriented towards basic sciences, preparing nurses to act as physician-assistants. Undertrained, underutilized and inadequately managed doctors and nurses greatly inhibit the efficiency and effectiveness of the Georgian health care system. 2. During the Soviet period, one graduate and one post-graduate medical school provided all medical training in Georgia. After the break-up of the FSU, due to the increasing number of candidates and the refusal of other republics to admit foreign medical students, the Ministry of Education (MoE) granted authorization to 28 new private medical schools. There is no accreditation procedure for these schools, no quality standard for teaching, no career track for faculty, no reliable register for trainers and trainees, and no licensing or certification procedure for graduates. The total number of medical students in all schools is now around 2,500, about 10 times the requirement of the country. Similar problems are found in the post-graduate medical education system. There are no criteria for selection of persons to receive resident training, no standards to judge the quality of the training programs, and no process for certification of specialists once they have completed training. 3. The educational system does not provide the knowledge and skills necessary to carry out competency-based and evidence-based care comparable to international standards. The fragmentation of the medical system is evident. In medical schools, separate faculties exist for paediatrics, sanitation and hygiene and military medicine. Few of the various health care institutions or agencies serving special populations collaborate with each other, which creates an inefficient system. Several key educational components are absent: a. There are no medical personnel qualified as general practitioners. Professionals who serve in this area lack proper training. As a result, many areas of care, and especially maternal and child health care, are inadequately served. Both the continuity of primary care and the ability to provide comprehensive care are seriously impeded. b. Public health is narrowly defined to mean infectious diseases control. Simple enforcement of hygienic norms does not address health promotion. Disease prevention programs are needed as non-communicable and life-style related diseases contribute increasingly to the burden of disease in the society. c. The administration and management of the health care system are hampered by insufficient management skills. These are essential in the changing financial and regulatory environment arising from an increased autonomy of providers, performance- based financing schemes and the introduction of health insurance.

 ADnnx C6 Page 1 of 11 MODERNIZATION OF THE HEALTH FINANCING SYSTEM A. Background 1. The Georgian health care financing reforms are being launched amidst general economic decline, worsening levels of health status, collapse of sector organization and finance, long term deterioration of health facilities, and long-standing inefficiencies and inequities in medical provision. 2. As in all formerly Soviet countries, there is a tendency to ignore positive features of the former health system. The system was universal and general. A strong network of hospitals and polyclinics was available. Significant steps in controlling infectious diseases such as tuberculosis had been made. Indeed the system may have been particularly adept at tackling health problems due to poverty. Nevertheless, there is little doubt that the former system was characterized by severe imbalances and inefficiencies. For example: a) The method of resource allocation exacerbated regional and inter-household inequalities in service provision. Resources were allocated on the basis of capacity number of beds and number of doctors and past levels of activity and political influence, rather than on the basis of patient need, efficiency or other suitable criteria. b) Line budgeting favored the employment of staff over expenditure on material items (e.g. drugs, medical supplies, food and fuel, etc.). c) Management capacity needed for efficient finance and provision of health care was severely limited. d) First-contact facilities were frequently staffed by poorly qualified or inexperienced staff with little financial motivation to treat patients effectively and efficiently. e) Poorly planned investment and training programmes resulted in an accumulation of acute care facilities that have left Georgia with a doctor/population ratio that is among t he highest in the world. Occupancy rates are well below 40 percent and the surplus of personnel is around 60 percent of current staffing. 3. A key feature of the system inherited from the Soviet period is illegal or under-the-table gratuity payments. These payments are deeply ingrained in the country's culture and have only a tenuous relationship to levels of activity or quality of care. By their very nature, no reliable figures are available on the extent of such payments. Anecdotal evidence suggests that they are obtained by staff at all levels of the health service although the main payments are likely to go to hospital doctors. 4. Though under-the-table payments are unquantifiable, there is broad agreement that they are a major distortion to the health care delivery process. For example, it is likely that specialists in psychiatric care receive little extra income. In contrast, surgical specialists, particularly gynecologists providing a quick and plainly beneficial service, can increase income substantially. Some gratuity money is given to encourage good quality care but money is also given by patients who fear not being treated at all. Despite the possibility of some type of price discrimination in determining the size of
 Annex C.6 Page 2 of 11 gratuity payments, it is likely that access to effective treatrnent is hindered by doctors who give priority to those able to pay or who keep patients waiting in hospital for operations. 5. Over the last three years the MoH has developed a reform program aimed at guaranteeing an acceptable and affordable level of services to the population and correcting structural deficiencies of the health service that existed before the collapse of the Soviet Union and the subsequent civil war. These reforms will greatly change the way in which services are organized and financed, and have the potential of arresting the current imbalances and inefficiencies. B. Health Expenditures: Levels, Trends and Composition' 6. While Georgia was part of the Soviet Union, the health sector was underfunded, receiving from 2.8 to 4.1 percent of GDP. With the current collapse of the economy the situation has become worse. Since 1992, the real value of public expenditures on health has fallen dramatically. While the exact fall in real expenditures is difficult to estimate due to a very high rate of inflation, using IMF price indices, the real value of public expenditures on health in 1993 were estimated to be less than 15 percent of the value for 1990 and in 1994 less than 10 percent of the 1990 value. In 1994, public expenditures on health fell to 0.3 percent of GDP and 1.3 percent of public sector expenditures. In 1994, annual public expenditures on health averaged less than US$1 per person.  Annex C.6 Page 3 of 11 C. Collapse of Government Revenues 8. Under the structure of health financing that Georgia inherited from the Soviet system, health care was primarily financed from the government budget. Localities were allocated funds using a formula based on the number of hospital beds and physicians. Parallel agencies, such as the Railways and the Interior Ministry, were also provided funds from the central budget for their own health activities. 9. A small amount of revenue also came from official charges for some drugs and a limited set of health care services and goods such as eye glasses and hearing aids. The amount of revenue collected in Georgia from these payments is not known, however, based on information from Russia, Kyrghyzstan and Estonia, it is estimated that these private sources were equal to 15 percent of the total state expenditures on health. In addition for many years it has been an accepted, but illegal and undocumented practice to make informal private payments to physicians for services. Presently, no data are available for estimating these informal payments. 10. The structure of revenue sources for the health sector has changed dramatically over the last three years. With the collapse of government revenues from 1991 to 1994, the private sector has become the major source of revenues. In the absence of an adequate household expenditure survey, however, it is not possible to give a credible estimate of the total value of private expenditures. The amount may, however, total as much as 75 percent of total sector expenditures. 11. The government's policy response to increase revenues for the sector has been to introduce a State Health Program which is financed from a mandatory payroll tax for health with 3 percent employer contribution and 1 percent employee contribution. This will be supplemented by revenues from privatization, licensing fees, and interest income as well as a sizable allocation from general government revenues in order to cover costs to administration, public health services, services for the poor, and services for veterans. 12. In addition to the State Health Program, which is administered by the State Health Fund, municipalities are obligated to provide a package of services under the Municipal Program. For the period from August 10 - December 31, the government mandated that municipalities spend a minimum of 1.3 lari (US$1) per inhabitant for this program. The minimum annual spending level for municipalities for 1996 has been set at 2.2 laris per person. Many municipalities, such as Tbilisi, Kutaisi, and Rustavi, are spending two to three times the minimum amount. A recent government decree (September 13, 1995) further obligates municipalities to pay for 90 percent of the utility expenses of health facilities located in their jurisdiction. This subsidy will be phased out over time. 13. The introduction of the State Health Fund along with the mandated expenditure levels at the municipal level will increase total resources going to the health sector. For example, projected monthly expenditures for December 1995 are 3.5 million laris compared to average monthly expenditures of 1.2 million lari for the first half of the year.  Annex C.6 Page 7 of 11 Provider payment methodology 24. The provider payment system is a key issue to the success of a health reform process in any country. Different methods generate incentives that influence decisively how providers produce health services. Depending on the nature of those incentives and on the context they are applied, payment mechanisms may induce, or not, movement toward improved efficiency, equity, consumer satisfaction and health status. 25. The reimbursement system designed by the MoH for the basic package combines essentially two methods: a case based system for hospitals and capitation for some public health activities. In the case-based methodology for hospitals, several nosological categories were defined under the 'basic package', and for each one a standard level of health services was defined and priced. Hospitals will be reimbursed by the State Health Fund for all patients who are admitted with diagnosis covered by the basic package. The unit prices include the quantity of medical consultations and tests for diagnosis purposes, the 'required' drugs and treatment medical acts and also the number of inpatient days for each category. One concern is the paucity of available information. This kind of payment methodology requires a significant amount of reliable information on costs and health services production, which does not seem to be available. This information system is indispensable to build the model and also to monitor its operation. 26. The reimbursement system for hospitalization designed by the MoH team is clearly too complicated, administratively costly, and provides perverse incentives to providers and consumers. The possible perverse effects of such a reimbursement methodology are quite well known and described extensively in the literature. One particularly telling example from Georgia is the case of child deliveries where the price of a normal delivery has been set at US$61, while for a Cesarean the price is US$ 300, and for a Cesarean with ICU the price is US$1200. These prices, paying almost twenty times more for a delivery which includes a stay of the mother in an ICU relative to a 'normal' delivery has some negative impacts: (i) it is a strong incentive to increase artificially the utilization of more sophisticated resources, causing an increase of health care costs (exactly the opposite to the intentions of the reimbursement system), thereby reducing efficiency; and (ii) it may cause some iatrogenic effects on the patients. 27. For public health services covered by the basic package, such as immunization and some matemal and child health services, providers will be paid an age-adjusted capitation fee ranging from US$1 to US$2 per capita. The details of how this system will be implemented, however, remain unclear 28. The most important source of revenue for health care provision will continue to be direct payments from patients The co-existence of these reimbursement systems raises an important issue, because the official one intends to be an incentive to efficiency, standardizing all the diagnosis and treatment procedures; the direct payments are an open-ended system with incentives to providers to increase sector expenditures. There is a clear issue of adverse consequences for patients. This problem with cost containment will add to the economic difficulties that the GoG has to finance even the very narrow basic package to be covered by the state health program.
 Annex C.6 Page 8 of 11 Coverage and Access 29. Historically, coverage of health services has been quite high in Georgia. Although there were regional differences in the availability of medical services, coverage and access were adequate. The country's financial crisis, however, has greatly limited the availability of affordable, adequate quality health facilities. Helicopters which once served the mountainous regions in winter no longer function. Ambulance services have dropped dramatically, further limiting the physical access for many people. Furthermore, there is evidence that many poor people cannot afford to pay the amounts currently required for medicine, drugs, and food in addition to the payments they must make to physicians and nurses. A 1994 national household survey found that 27 percent of the poor were unable to afford medical care. These physical and financial limitations to access may explain the decline in utilization rates for hospitalization and outpatient visits over the last three years. As an example, in 1994 around 10 percent of pregnant women gave birth at home because they could not afford the costs for a normal delivery. 30. With two thirds of the population under the poverty line and approximately 800,000 in the most vulnerable groups (including more than 270,000 displaced people), the Government is exploring ways to ensure that the very poor will have access to the essential health services which are not included in the basic benefits package. The two issues which remain unresolved are: (1) how to identify the poorest in an economy where a large part of the activity is informal and poverty is a widespread yet new social phenomena and (2) how to finance a subsidized program to support access to basic health services by the poor when public financial resources are extremely scarce and institutional capabilities are very weak. In the short-term, the Government chose to address the needs of the poor by designating Hospital Number 9 and several specialty hospitals to serve the needs of the poor. A total of 275 beds were designated to treat the most vulnerable groups in Tbilisi: single unemployed mothers with three or more children, single pensioners with pensions below US$2 and single invalids. Other institutions, like the Veteran's Hospital, are financed by the State to continue providing care to their clients. The Government has since refined the system by providing vouchers to the groups identified above and allowing them free choice of provider. Improved means testing with a World Bank supported household income survey planned for 1996 and a second household demand and expenditure survey, replicating the one prepared by UNICEF in August-September 1995, is planned for September 1998, to provide information on poverty evolution and its implications on health. In the future, the government may wish to improve the horizontal equity of its health system by encouraging risk adjustments other than age in its capitation payments to providers and to improve vertical equity by looking at sources of revenue that are more progressive. The health financing component has three major objectives: (1) assure that scarce resources are used in a cost-effective manner to improve the health of the Georgian population; (2) assure the equitable distribution of financing both in the collection and allocation of public funds, with special emphasis on the position of socially vulnerable groups and the balance of individual and collective responsibility for health; and (3) assure sustainable financing of the health sector in order to meet population needs. The project proposes to meet these objectives through the following activities:

 Annex D Page 1 of 17 ECONOMIC ANALYSIS A. Introduction 1. The proposed project is multifaceted. It addresses not only major macro policy issues in the health sector such as health care financing, regulating health care providers, and changing public/private roles, but also supports targeted interventions in maternal and child health and health promotion in order to address the diseases which cause the greatest burden in Georgia. The following economic analysis provides the rationale for why this project at this time, and describes the potential impact of both the proposed project and the Government's health sector reform strategy. The analysis follows the framework recommended by the World Bank's Human Development Department (HDD), addressing the following issues: 1) linkages to economic and sector work (section B); 2) analysis of alternatives (section C); 3) assessment of financial and fiscal impact, public and private affordability, and cost recovery (section D); 4) analysis of cost-effectiveness, cost utility, and cost benefit (section E); 5) sensitivity and risk analysis (section F); 6) analysis of institutional capacity (section G); 7) analysis of poverty alleviation impact (section H); 8) analysis of environmental impact (section I); 9) performance criteria for monitoring and evaluation (section J); and 10) overall coherence and completeness of analysis (section K). B. Linkages to Economic and Sector Work Strategy for World Bank Assistance 2. The objectives of the World Bank's assistance strategy to Georgia are: to help reverse the sharp economic decline of the past few years, to assist the transition to a market economy and alleviate the poverty which has emerged in Georgia in recent years. With a particular focus on promoting private sector development and improving the efficiency of the public sector ... through its lending program, the Bank will support economy-wide and sector-specific reforms that promote economic growth as well as investments to rehabilitate and build new capacity in critical infrastructure sectors. The Bank will also assist in strengthening public management, developing human resource and institutional capacities and strengthening the social safety net. 3. Given Georgia's difficult fiscal situation, much of the World Bank's assista nce will concentrate on improving the cost-effectiveness of government programs and on redirecting public sector involvement in the economy. Strengthening the social safety net and targeting scarce public resources to the provision of public goods and to fight against poverty are the major strategic objectives in the social sectors. Plans to reform the health sector to improve service delivery to the poor and to privatize the system where possible would not only reduce obligations on the state budget and improve resource allocation efficiency, but would also help to strengthen Georgia's social safety net.
