The proposed health project fully complies with and supports the World Bank's assistance strategy in Georgia by attempting to: a) improve the efficiency of the health care system; b) create conditions for privatizing health facilities; c) reduce the government's financial role to providing a basic package of public health and essential clinical services so as to free resources for targeting the poorest and reinforcing the social safety net; d) improve health services for the poor by standardizing the quality of services and offering a package of public health and essential clinical services free of charge; and e) in the longer term, improve the economic productivity of labor by reducing the burden of disease, especially among adult males. Economic and Sector Work (ESW) 5. To gain a more in-depth understanding of the constraints and possibilities of the Georgian economy, detailed economic and sector work has been completed. In health, most of the ESW was carried out as part of project preparation. The objectives of the ESW, done in close collaboration with Georgian colleagues, were to assess the current situation in the health sector, assist the Government in designing a feasible reform for the sector, and identify and assess various alternatives for a World Bank financed health project. Two series of technical notes were prepared (January 1995 and June 1995) covering topics such as: health status, maternal and child health, hospital efficiency, health facilities and medical equipment, health financing reform, poverty issues in the health reform, and accreditation, licensing, and quality assurance of health providers. Analysis done on the health sector as part of the upcoming Public Expenditure Review (PER) also provided invaluable information on health financing and health expenditures. This ESW was important in determining what the sectoral priorities were and how best to meet the Government and Bank's objectives of improving the efficiency of the sector, reducing the burden of disease, and alleviating poverty. The collaborative work allowed the World Bank to help the Government develop and refine a health sector reform strategy. The components of the project developed naturally from the priorities which were identified and the ensuing policy reforms adopted by the Government. Adequacy of Policy Framework 6. The Government is committed to a health sector reform which increases public spending on health, ensures coverage of essential health services to the entire population, improves quality of health care services, and increases efficiency of the system. Universal coverage and broad risk pooling were positive features of the old system. However, with the total collapse of the economy and civil unrest, public provision of services essentially stopped. Utilization rates dropped, indicating reduced access. The risk pooling which characterized the old system was eliminated as patients were forced to make illegal payments to doctors and nurses for health care services. The Government-'s response to this crisis has been radical. It has changed the organization and financing of health services by separating the provision and financing of health care, introduced new sources of financing for the sector, and concentrated public spending on a package of public health and essential clinical services. 7. While these policy changes mirror many of the reforms taking place in other middle income countries, it should be noted that the objectives of risk pooling and broad access are somewhat compromised. First, although the reforms broaden the financial base of the sector beyond general revenues by introducing new payroll and excise taxes, the existing low rates of tax collection and large quantity of services that will be paid out of pocket mean that risk pooling is not universal. However, risk pooling under the reforms will be broader than has been present in the totally unregulated system of the last four years. Similarly, access to services will not be guaranteed as was the case during the
 Annex D Page 3 of 17 Soviet era, but the reforms, by guaranteeing a package of public health and essential clinical services, should ensure broader access than has been present since independence. 8. Restoration of economic growth should improve both risk pooling and coverage. In that case, presumably the tax base would expand and the scope of the basic package would increase, reducing the need for out-of-pocket payments by patients. 9. One risk of the health financing reform is cost escalation. The old system was controlled by the central government. Under the new system, health care providers will be reimbursed for services provided on the basis of a diagnostic related group (DRG) type fee schedule. The difficulties in controlling costs in such a system are well documented in the United States and other Western European countries, and even more difficult to control in a country like Georgia with little existing infrastructure to closely monitor provider behavior. Some steps have been taken to control costs such as capitating public health services and establishing a reference price list for services not included in the basic package. Perhaps as a reaction to the former system, however, the Georgians have been very reluctant to adopt other payment methods in order to better contain costs. The project will attempt to strengthen the Government's capacity to control health expenditures by closely monitoring the State Health Fund (a credit covenant) and supporting the development of practice guidelines and training programs to improve the quality and appropriateness of care provided. 10. The reforms, as described above, are fully consistent with the Government's public sector investment strategy. The project has been designed to support the Government's health sector strategy and is consistent with both the Government's health sector investment strategy as well as more broadly its public sector investment strategy. C. Analysis of Alternatives 11. The project's objectives -- to reduce the burden of disease, to improve the efficiency of the sector, and to improve coverage and access -- complement both the World Bank's assistance strategy for Georgia (see para 2) as well as the Government's economic reform strategy. Alternatives in project design were assessed against their contribution to meeting these objectives. Factors which influenced the choice of alternatives included a project budget constraint (IDA funding of only US$12 million at the time of appraisal and limited Government contribution), the relative cost-effectiveness of the alternatives, and political will and implementation capacity. Alternatives to Reduce the Burden of Disease 12. The overall objective for the Government with regard to health is to improve the health status of the population. The known determinants of health are socio-economic conditions, individual life-styles, the health care system and the environment. Consequently, interventions which promote economic growth will also have a positive impact on health status. Georgia is undertaking economic reform with the assistance of the IMF and the World Bank and positive growth is expected to begin in 1996. However, improvements in living standards will be gradual and a return to 1993 levels of consumption is not expected until the turn of the century. Improvements in health status attributable to economic growth will lag even further. Improvements in the environment are not expected to greatly improve health status in Georgia. A recent study found that less than one percent of the burden of disease in Former Soviet republics is caused by inadequate water or sewerage systems. The project,
 Annex D Page 4 of 17 therefore, emphasizes improving the health care system and changing the life-styles of individuals in order to reduce the burden of disease. 13. A burden of disease analysis was undertaken as part of project preparation. The results of the analysis, using the disability adjusted life year (DALYs) methodology, show that the two groups where the most DALYs are lost due to premature deaths are infants (population under one year of age) and individuals aged 60 to 64 years. Fifty percent of infant deaths occur in the perinatal period. Looking across diseases, the study found that cerebro-vascular disorders and ischemic diseases are the most important health problems in Georgia, followed by accidents for men and breast cancer for women. On the basis of this study as well as what was learned from economic and sector work, the project was designed with two very specific targets: a) reduce perinatal mortality and permanent disabilities by improving the quality of maternal and child health services and b) reduce adult mortality and morbidity by preventing circulatory diseases and accidents by improving public information and prevention programs. 14. Project activities which are intended to improve the quality of maternal and child health services include: a) strengthening the MoH's institutional capacity to develop health policies, health promotion activities and services for women and infants including development of protocols of care, rules for licensing staff and facilities, guidelines for privatizing and reorganizing services, and a perinatal mortality surveillance system; b) developing training programs in maternal and child health, obstetrics and pediatrics; c) creating a national Task Force for Child and Maternal Survival, which will build national commitment, increase funding, and develop public awareness of child and maternal survival issues; d) creating regional Perinatal Centers in Tbilisi and Kutaisi with a referral system to treat all high risk pregnancies and newborns with complications and demonstrate to residents and other hospitals how perinatal services may be improved; and e) refurbishing and equipping of maternal and child health services in the Tsageri District Hospital to demonstrate how to improve services in remote areas; and 15. The project aims to reduce perinatal mortality by improving the quality of existing maternal and child health services. This was determined to be both more effective and less expensive than introducing new services. Refurbishment of the two Perinatal Centers in Tbilisi and Kutaisi is the most expensive input in the project. The Ministry of Health first identified 16 facilities nationwide as potential candidates. An assessment was made of each of these facilities and the two facilities chosen on the basis of their geographical location, projected cost of refurbishment, political commitment of the mayors, willingness of the hospital directors to undertake reforms, and the preferences of the Ministry of Health. The Tbilisi facility will also offer cardiac services and serve as the center for a secondary cardiac care prevention program, which is discussed below. 16. To address the problems of adult health, the project invests in smoking reduction, cardio-vascular diseases prevention and injury control programs. The cost-effectiveness of health promotion and disease prevention is well known and substantiated in a cost-effectiveness analysis which was completed as part of project preparation (see paras 39-40). Given the lag in achieving measurable improvements in health status for some programs such as circulatory diseases, the project will also support a secondary prevention program which is intended to educate the public on the symptoms of heart attacks and strokes in order to encourage them to seek timely treatment and also educate health professionals on the best treatment. In order to improve the likelihood of success of these prevention programs, the project will establish a health promotion fund which will provide grants to comnmunities, NGOs, and governmental agencies on a competitive basis. Alternatives which were rejected included administering the programs through the existing San-Epid system or distributing
 Annex D Page 5 of 17 monies to communities strictly on a per-capita basis. The project will also have a positive impact on adult health by training health professionals in modem public health practice and family medicine. Alternatives to Improve Efficiency and Quality 17. Economic and sector work revealed that one of the major problems Georgia faces is an excess supply of both doctors and hospitals. Furthermore, the quality of health services is poor because health professionals are poorly trained and the health infrastructure is in a poor state of repair and often inadequately equipped. In order to improve the efficiency of the sector, the project will reduce the size and improve the quality of health sector personnel by: (a) removing physicians and other personnel from the government payroll, allowing competition to rationalize the number in the sector; (b) instituting a licensing exam for currently practicing as well as recently graduated physicians; (c) creating a Center for Continuing Education to provide training in public health, family medicine, nursing, and administration to existing health personnel; and (d) limiting the entry to medical schools. These actions were chosen over other alternatives because they would rationalize the supply of doctors in a transparent way and allow the best quality doctors to continue to practice while providing training for others in critical areas. There was debate as to whether it was necessary to regulate the entry to medical schools or allow the market to control supply. However, with more than 28 medical schools opening since 1992, the Government requested the Bank's support in taking such drastic measures. Whether to base the Center for Continuing Education within one of the existing medical faculties was also considered and ultimately rejected because it was felt that it would be difficult to change the existing establishment, including the attitudes of the faculty and easier to have a free-standing entity which could hire guest faculty on the basis of their qualifications. 18. The project will reduce the number and improve the quality and efficiency of health care facilities by: (a) privatizing most facilities and granting management autonomy to those that remain in the public sector, creating a mixed, potentially competitive public/private market for patient services; (b) reimbursing facilities for services delivered rather than by the number of beds and other norms; (c) licensing and accrediting all health facilities; (d) introducing preventive maintenance of facilities and equipment, and upgrading service quality and management; and (e) refurbishing three existing facilities where perinatal services will be offered and as a demonstration of how to improve efficiency within existing facilities. This approach is based on the belief that before undertaking major physical refurbishment of the existing health care infrastructure, the number of facilities must be reduced and incentive systems developed to improve the internal efficiency of the institutions. The health facilities will be refurbished under the project, including the Kutaisi Pediatric and Maternity Hospitals, which agreed to merge, will be a powerful demonstration of how to better efficiency as well as provide integrated maternal and child health services. If more money were available from IDA, the project would have financed additional refurbishment once rationalization of the sector had occurred. 19. The project will improve the allocative efficiency of health services in Georgia by supporting the Government's state health program which shifts scarce public resources from primarily curative care to a basic package of public health (immunization, healthy children and safe motherhood, prevention of socially dangerous diseases, epidemiological surveillance, and health promotion) and essential clinical services (deliveries, treatment of children under the age of 14, treatment of TB, inpatient psychiatric care, provision of drugs for terminally ill patients, and emergency services). The remaining services are provided fee-for-service, with exemptions made for the most vulnerable groups. The items included in the basic package were selected using six criteria: epidemiological significance, social significance, life-threatening conditions, need for emergency care, effectiveness of medical intervention, and cost of treatment. Support will be provided under the project to evaluate and expand the contents of this basic package.
 Annex D Page 6 of 17 Alternatives to Improve Coverage and Access 20. Between 1990 and 1994, public finance for health services collapsed in Georgia. The system only survived because of surreptitious payments from patients to doctors and nurses. With deliveries costing as much as $150 and cesarean sections between $300 and $400, it is not surprising that utilization rates fell by fifty percent. The alternative the Government has chosen to improve coverage is guaranteeing access to a basic package of public health and essential clinical services described above. The Government did consider charging those who could afford to pay co-payments for clinical services included in the basic package in order to be able to expand services for the poor. However, this idea was rejected for now because of the difficulties in means testing. Ultimately, universal coverage and access will only be achievable when the economy improves. Public/Private Justification 21. The government's strategy is to privatize most of the delivery of health services, eventually retaining only regional hospitals in the public domain and converting the Ministry of Health's role to one primarily of regulation. Until facilities are privatized, they will be managerially independent in an attempt to improve their internal efficiency. Privatization of dental clinics and pharmacies has already begun and is proceeding well. These are the types of services, however, for which the private sector is most likely to want and be able to deliver. It is less certain that the Government will succeed in privatizing a sufficient number of hospitals to ensure adequate geographical coverage for the population. This mix of public and private facilities will need to be monitored in order to ensure that socially optimal amounts of care are provided. 22. On the financing side, market failures dictate a larger role for the public sector. While the Government is shifting more responsibility of financing to a payroll tax, it will continue to allocate funds from general revenues to health care to cover the costs of services which are public goods or have large externalities. These include public health services with transmission externalities such as prevention of communicable diseases, as well as services which can prevent disabilities, which place a large economic burden on society. Maternal and child health services, for example, can prevent disabilities associated with low birth weight and delivery complications. D. Financial Assessment Financial and Fiscal Impact 23. While Georgia was part of the Soviet Union, the health sector received from 2.8 to 4.1 % of GDP. The situation grew worse with the collapse of the economy. In 1994, public expenditures on health fell to 0.3% of GDP and 1.3% of public sector expenditures. Annual public expenditures on health averaged less than US$1 per person in 1994, less than 10% of 1990 expenditure levels in real terms. The fall in real expenditures was accompanied by a shift in the line item composition of expenditures. The rising costs of heating oil and other hard currency supplies crowded out spending on wages and maintenance in an increasingly limited budget. In 1990, wages and supplements were 52% of total public sector health expenditures. By 1993, they had fallen to 39% and in 1994 to 32% of the totals.
 Annex D Page 7 of 17 24. The Government is aware that restoring health expenditures to past levels would be impossible and undesirable, and is undertaking reforms (privatization and introduction of user charges) to transfer to the private sector responsibility for the provision and financing of health services. But with the current decline in income, this could lead to an irreversible deterioration of the human and physical stock of the country, jeopardizing the potential for growth. At current levels of public expenditure, it is also likely that the poor will have limited access to basic social services. The macro economic prospects are such that even with timely implementation of reforms, Georgia's economy will not reach the 1993 levels of per-capita consumption (already depressed relative to 1990) before the end of the century. 25. The government's policy response to increase revenues for the sector has been to introduce a mandatory payroll tax for health with 3 percent employer contribution and I percent employee contribution. Central budget allocations for health as well as revenues from the payroll tax, privatization, licensing fees, and interest income will go to the newly created State Health Fund (SHF). The SHF will act as a financial intermediary and reimburse both public and private health care providers for a basic package of preventive and essential clinical health care services included in the State Health Program. In addition municipalities are obligated to provide a package of services under the Municipal Health Program. With these additional sources of revenues, public sector health spending is projected to reach US$3.68 per capita in 1995 and US$9 in 1996. Using World Bank/IMF macro-economic projections as well as reasonable assumptions about the health sector, public sector spending on health should reach US$20 (1995 $) per capita by the year 2000 or 2.6% of GDP. Health care services not included in the State Health Program or the Municipal Health Program will be paid for out-of-pocket by consumers. 26. The current level of payroll taxes are quite high in Georgia: 45 % combined contribution rate for social security, unemployment insurance, and health insurance. Tax collection, however, remains extremely low, increasing only from 3 percent of GDP in 1994 to 3.5 % in the first half of 1995. There are a small number of contributors and low reported wages in the formal sector. The World Bank has been sufficiently concerned with the adverse effects on labor and production costs that a condition of the Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) is to reduce the contribution rate to Employment Fund by 2 percentage points and reduce the contribution rate to the United Fund for Social Security and Social Insurance by 8 percentage points. Given the plans to reduce total tax burden, the 4% payroll tax for health is believed to be manageable. The Government has kept the rate low compared to other countries such as Hungary (14%) and Croatia (20%) by relying on other sources of finance for health. The "3 + 1 " payroll tax accounts for approximately 25 % of the revenues of the State Health Fund. 27. Even with additional sources of financing, however, government revenues will remain insufficient to finance critical public expenditures without increased efficiency and reallocation of public spending. One key issue to address is the inefficiency of the low wages in the budgetary sector. The budgetary sector in Georgia is marked by two distinct traits: overemployment combined with a scarcity of key skills and extremely low pay. Low wages, a result of budgetary constraints, can cause government workers to spend much of their time looking for additional sources of income and makes it difficult to attract or retain skilled workers. This not only lowers efficiency, but also jeopardizes the Government's ability to perform basic functions. Aware of these issues, the Government initiated a policy of labor retrenchment, reducing the number of positions in the budgetary sector about 40 percent between January and December 1995. Nearly two-thirds (120,000) of these positions were in the health sector. As part of the health sector reform, employees of the health sector were gradually removed from the government payroll. Those that remain employed are paid directly by the hospitals and clinics that have become managerially independent firms.

Affordability of the reformslGovernmentperspective: The Government's reform program is designed in such a way to be "affordable" given the country's current economic crisis. Minimum allocations for health are being included in the SAC and health spending has been discussed by the IMF and COD. Public sector financing for the sector is projected to increase, but still remain at an affordable 2 to 3 % of GDP over the next decade. There are nonetheless, concerns about the sustainability of central budget financing (approximately 50% of the Fund) and the ability of the Government to collect the tax revenues earmarked for the Fund (25% from payroll taxes and 10% from excise taxes). Furthermore, government projections show State Health Fund expenditures exceeding revenues by approximately 11 million lari in 1996. These Government estimates of expenditures are based on current utilization patterns and do not consider latent demand that is suppressed by unaffordability or poor quality of services. If the Government is unable to control utilization, the cost of the basic package will exceed projections and add to the projected deficit. The project will address these issues by requiring quarterly statements from the Fund and providing technical assistance during the project, particularly for developing the MIS necessary to monitor the system as well as for revising the provider payment method if necessary. 29. Affordability of the reforms/private perspective. The affordability of health care services for the population has been a major concern of both the World Bank and the Government. A national survey found that 27 % of the population could not afford essential health services. The total collapse of the public system has left patients responsible for paying for all health care. And the care is not cheap. The average price of a delivery is US$150, compared to an average per capita income of US$363 in 1995. The project, by supporting a basic package of essential and public health services will make health services available free of charge. It will also increase household incomes by decreasing the burden of disease for disability and death. 30. With two thirds of the population under the Government's defined poverty line and approximately 800,000 in the most vulnerable groups (including more than 270,000 displaced people), the Government is exploring ways to ensure that the very poor will have access to the essential health services which are not included in the basic benefits package. The two issues which remain unresolved are: (1) how to identify the poorest in an economy where a large part of the activity is informal and poverty is a widespread yet new social phenomena and (2) how to finance a subsidized program to support access to basic health services by the poor when public financial resources are extremely scarce and institutional capabilities are very weak. 31. Initially, the Government has chose to address the problem by designating Hospital #9 and several specialty hospitals to serve the needs of the poor. A total of 275 beds were designated to treat the most vulnerable groups free of charge: single unemployed mothers with three or more children, single pensioners with pensions below US$2 and single invalids. Other institutions, like the Veteran's Hospital, were financed by the State to continue providing care to their clients. In February 1996, the Government revised the system by providing vouchers to the targeted groups and allowing them to use any health facility of their choice. In order to monitor the affordability of health services under the reform, the project includes a study of utilization to monitor private expenditures and financial barriers to access. 32. Affordability of the project: The tentative project financing plan includes US$7.7 million in Government contribution. This amount includes all applicable taxes and duties, estimated to

E. Burden of Disease Study and Cost-Effectiveness Analysis of Health Interventions 34. As part of project preparation, a study was undertaken to analyze the cost-effectiveness of several proposed programs in disease prevention and maternal and child care to be included in the project: reduction of tobacco consumption; cardio-vascular disease prevention, and traffic injury control. The project will finance perinatal centers in both Tbilisi and Kutaisi, but only Kutaisi was included in this analysis because at the time of the study the site for the Tbilisi center had not been selected and cost estimates were unavailable. The study had the following specific objectives: (a) to estimate the burden of disease in Georgia, studying its distribution by nosologies, age, and gender; (b) to estimate present health care costs associated with the health problems targeted under the project; (c) to estimate potential health gains achievable through the interventions; and (d) to analyze the cost- effectiveness of the three prevention programs and the Kutaisi MCH program.
 Annex D Page 10 of 17 Methodology2 35. The 1993 World Development Report recommends estimating the burden of disease by calculating the number of Disability Adjusted Life Years -- DALYs -- lost because of death and illness. DALYs combine into a single measure the number of years of life lost due to premature death and years of life lived with a disability. Unfortunately, morbidity data in Georgia are unreliable, therefore, the global burden of disease analysis was completed using data only on mortality. However, in order to estimate more accurately the burden of diseases targeted in the project's disease prevention program, morbidity data from Estonia were combined with Georgia's data to produce estimates of "disability" DALYs for the following diseases: ischemic heart disease, lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), cerebro-vascular disease, and traffic accidents. The study uses 1990 mortality data as the baseline because these data were determined to be the most reliable. 36. To estimate the cost-effectiveness of the proposed programs, the study compares what would happen if the programs were not implemented with the expected cost and benefits as described in the project's Staff Appraisal Report. The cost estimates took into account: a) direct costs of diagnosis, treatment, follow-up and other health care services; b) quantifiable indirect costs (losses in production); and c) costs of implementing the program. A discount rate of 3% was applied to all costs as well as to all DALYs saved.3 Burden of Disease 37. The two age groups where the number of life years lost due to premature death is greatest are infants under the age of one and adults aged 60 to 64. In 1990, for example, 1,557 potential life years were lost (using standard life expectancies) because of partially avoidable infant deaths. These results clearly justify the existence of a strong MCH component in the Georgia Health Project. Further analysis of the DALYs lost by cause (Table 1) suggests that the project's emphasis on preventing smoking, cardio-vascular disease, and traffic accidents is well targeted. The main health problems of Georgia, in terms of years of life lost to premature death, are ischemic disease, stroke, and atherosclerosis. Other important causes of death are accidents and trauma, particularly for men, and breast cancer for women. In the middle of this short list of main causes of death is cirrhosis and other diseases of the liver, most likely related to alcohol consumption. 38. Table 1 only considers the life years lost due to premature death, which underestimates the importance of some diseases which are not major contributors to death, but do result in significant losses due to disability. Taking into account all these issues, the main conclusions of the study are: i) the three prevention programs included in the Georgia Health Project are related to major adult health problems of the Georgian population, which caused in 1990 an estimated loss of 432,805 DALYs; ii) assuming the effectiveness and the expected outcomes of the proposed prevention programs, there is a potential to save 198,908 DALYs by the year 2005 at an average cost of US$2.83 for each DALY saved; ii) for each US dollar spent on prevention under the project, US$63 can be saved in treatment and indirect costs. These figures show that the programs have a high level of cost-effectiveness. In addition, the Kutaisi maternal and child health component of the project targets one of the groups contributing the most years of life lost to society due to premature death --infants. The component could save 16,489 years of life at an average cost of US$138 per life saved. F. Risk Analysis 44. The Government faces substantial financial, political and institutional risks in implementing both its ambitious health care reform program as well as the project. A full risk assessment was not done as part of project preparation. However, to the extent possible, risks were quantified as part of sensitivity analyses of the project's benefits. For example, sensitivity analyses included as part of the cost-effectiveness study found that changing the discount rate or expected program outcomes did not substantially change the study's conclusions. The project has also taken steps to address the most obvious risks associated with institutional capacity in the MoH to implement the project by setting up a strong PCU. Financial Risks 45. Given the collapse of the economy and the potential for high cost inflation in health spending, one of the major risks the Government faces is the financial sustainability of the health care reform. In projecting the fiscal impact of the reforms, simulations placed the range of per capita expenditures on health between US$8.34 and US$11.40 (8.6% and 11.3% of public sector spending) in 1996 and between US$20.64 and US$32.09 (8.6% and 13.5% of public sector spending) in the year 2000. In order to ensure continued Government commitment to the health sector even under a pessimistic macroeconomic scenario both the Health Project and the Structural Adjustment Credit have included minimum spending levels on health as conditions of lending. The Structural Adjustment Credit specifies that at least 7 % of public spending must go to health and that this amount should rise as revenues increase. Under the health project, the Government has been asked to provide assurances
 Annex D Page 15 of 17 that it would ensure the viability of the State Health Fund without reducing the scope of services included in the basic benefits package and monitor and provide to the World Bank quarterly financial statements of the Fund. 46. Another financial risk the project faces is the ability of the Government to contribute its part of project costs. Although the amount is felt to be reasonable given the size of the health budget (see para 32), the experience of the Municipal Infrastructure Project suggests that the Government may have difficulty meeting its obligations. In order to mitigate this risk, a condition of credit effectiveness will be that the Government open a counterpart contribution account and deposit US$400,000 into this account and continue to replenish this account quarterly. The Ministry of Finance has already written a letter to the World Bank pledging the necessary quarterly contributions. Political Risks 47. In the recent past, Georgia has been plagued by political instability, highlighted by civil wars and the assassination attempt on Mr. Shevardnadze. In July 1995, however, the Parliament approved a new constitution, paving the way for presidential and parliamentary elections. In November, Mr. Shevardnadze was elected president with a large majority. Since the elections, he has succeeded in purging the mnafia and it is expected that the new Government will be fully committed to the economic reforms. The Minister of Health, who is widely perceived to be one of the most reform minded members of the Government, will remain in his position along with most of his higher level staff. While the situation in Abkhazia has stabilized, a growing concern is the war in Chechnya and possibility it will spread to Georgia and other countries in the Caucasus region. 48. Another political risk is that the Government will encounter resistance to the reforms from important stakeholders such as doctors, hospitals, and medical schools. Much of the project emphasizes changing the behavior of providers, including what they practice (from highly specialized, curative medicine to primary health care), how they practice (from low quality, unregulated medicine to care guided by clinical practice standards), and the incentives they face (from salaried positions to one where earnings are based on productivity). There will be identifiable winners and losers in the reforms; a necessity if Georgia is to reduce the excess supply. The Government has tried to minimize this risk by providing good unemployment benefits for doctors and providing retraining for those who wish to change their specialty or leave the profession. Providers have had and will continue to have an important role in the preparation and implementation of the project, including areas such as developing licensing criteria, practice standards, and educational curricula. G. Institutional Capacity 49. Weak institutional capacity within the Government and the Ministry of Health remains a major risk, inspite of the recent political and legislative advances. The major issues are the management and administration capacity of the Ministry of Health, including its various departments and agencies such as the State Health Fund. To mitigate this risk, component coordinators were identified in each of the project's implementing agencies very early on in project preparation (October 1994). They will have primary responsibility for implementing the activities under their components. Much technical assistance and training was provided during project preparation and will continue during the project. The supervision plan for the project includes more than the average number of staff weeks. A more thorough institutional analysis, covering not only the Ministry but also health care providers, will be done as part of preparation for a second health project.

Analysis of Poverty Alleviation 51. The collapse of pubic financing for health care has left many Georgians without access to affordable health care. The Government's decision to reform the health sector is instrumental to the broader public sector reform, to the development of a sustainable social safety network, and an example of efficient use of scarce resources to fight against poverty. The project has a direct poverty reduction objective by creating conditions for the financially sustainable provision of a basic package of public health and essential clinical services. While most patients will still be required to pay for
 AnnexD Page 17 of 17 some services, the total financial burden should decrease. This is because while health care was nominally free, under the table payments have long been common in Georgia. For services not included in the basic package, the Government has been working on ways of better targeting for the poor. Action has already been taken in hospitals to set aside beds to treat the most vulnerable groups. The Government is also planning a quota system for every hospital to provide care for patients unable to pay for health services not included in the basic package of care. 52. By the end of 1996, with technical assistance provided under the SAC, a new backup program for social assistance will be established. This program is intended to address the problems of those who are needy but do not qualify for benefits under any existing program and can demonstrate that their resources are very limited. The test for eligibility under the new program will take into account the presence in the family of at least one person in vulnerable circumstances as well as the family's income and assets. Families will have to periodically demonstrate that they continue to meet the conditions for eligibility. The eligibility limits for this program will be set so that now more than a small proportion of the Georgian population -- 3 percent -- qualifies for assistance. These people will also be eligible for free care under the State Health Fund. The Government would also like to institute co-payments for the basic package for those who can pay once a reliable means testing system is in place, further freeing resources for the poor. J. Assessment of Environmental Impact 53. The project is expected to have a positive impact on the environment through energy efficiency measures that are part of the overall program to improve hospital efficiency. Medical waste disposal systems in hospitals and polyclinics were assessed during project preparation and under the project standards and norms will be developed for the rehabilitation of health facilities. It has been designated in Environmental Category C. K. Overall Coherence and Completeness of Analysis 54. The project is designed to support the Georgian health care reform program which is amongst the most progressive of all the former Soviet republics. In developing the reform, the Government has had to make tradeoffs in meeting conflicting objectives. For example, the new payroll tax for health raises additional revenue for the sector, but also will affect the competitiveness of industry and possibility of tax evasion. The new system will do less well at risk pooling and ensuring universal access than the former Soviet system, but will improve quality and ensure coverage of the most essential public health and clinical services. Most people will have to pay for health services not included in the basic package, but these payments will be legitimate and rationally priced rather than the illegal and unregulated system of gratuities which existed before. Government spending on health remains low, but it is higher than before and affordable, given the current economic situation. In the end, in the opinion of the project preparation team, the benefits of both the reform as well as the project outweigh the possible negative consequences and risks. The project will monitor closely the financial sustainability of the reforms and their effects on the poor and make special efforts to strengthen the capacity of the Ministry of Health to proceed with implementation.

 Annex page 31 of 33 IV. MONITORING, EVALUATION, AND REPORTING The selection of monitoring indicators should be guided by the following principles: 1) keeping the indicators simple and measurable and 2) linking the indicators to decision making. The choice of indicators is an ongoing process and the indicators below may be modified during project implementation. Strengthening the capacity of the Government to collect and analyze health data is included in the project. The project's Health Promotion Fund will also strengthen local capacity to monitor health activities by requiring grant recipients to demonstrate measurable outcomes of their projects. Two sets of indicators have been defined: process indicators (or input and output indicators) to measure progress in project implementation and impact indicators (or outcome and impact indicators) to evaluate improvements in the health system and the health status of the population. Most project inputs will be monitored as part of the Project's Implementation Schedule which was prepared in Microsoft Project. Key policy benchmarks included in the Statement of Development Objectives will also be monitored and reviewed annually by the World Bank and the Government.

 Annex E page 33 of 33 B. Progress Reporting Throughout the execution of the Project, semi-annual reports shall be sent to the World Bank from the project coordination unit. The following outline is proposed: (i) an executive summary; (ii) two pages of text describing progress, status, and problems encountered with the project component; (iii) updated implementation schedules, based on those presented in this annex and revised to highlight any differences between actual and anticipated project execution; (iv) fully completed monitoring indicator tables; and (v) financial statements. These elements of the reports are described in more detail below. (i) Executive Summary: A brief summary of the principal information contained in the report. The summary should emphasize, for the six month period in question, significant project developments, major problems encountered, corrective measures taken to overcome any implementation difficulties, and unusual events. An opinion should be given as to the overall progress and effectiveness of the implementation of the project components. (ii) Project Status: The document shall report on the progress of the component's implementation. Reference shall be made to the updated implementation schedules and any differences shall be explained in the text. Problems encountered in project execution shall be discussed and solutions proposed. Any other unusual events shall be presented. Staffing difficulties, both within the implementing agency and/or project coordination unit itself as well as those related to consultants and contractors involved in the Project, should be reported. This section should include information on any changes in project management arrangements and summaries on the performance of engineering and other consultants retained under the Project. A written synopsis shall be presented of the work carried out in the preceding six months and that to be undertaken in the coming six months. (iii) Implementation Schedules: The implementation schedules presented in this annex for the major components of the Project will be made available to the respective component coordinators and implementing agencies as software. In this way the execution of all the components and subcomponents will be effectively tracked and compared with the initial program. Graphic print outs of the schedules should be appended to the semi-annual progress reports. (iv) Monitoring Indicator Tables: The tables given above, which document changes in the monitoring indicators, shall be reproduced for each report and incorporated as appendices. (v) Project Financial Statements: Statements sunmmarizing project accounts should be the appendix to the semi-annual progress report.

doc.abstracts: The Health Project will support the health sector reform efforts the government has initiated and will aim to improve the health of the Georgian population. The project's specific objectives are to: 1) reorient the health system towards cost-effective public health interventions like preventive and primary health care, assuring, in particular, better quality care for women and children, and focusing the Ministry of Health's (MOH) activities on regulation of public and private providers; 2) rehabilitate selected facilities and equipment that were down-sized and dedicated to cost-effective provision of maternal, perinatal and pediatric care; 3) develop human resources to support health reform, through continuing education for public health doctors, family practitioners, nurses, health administrators, and other personnel; and 4) support the development of an independent health fund with regional branches, in order to finance a package of basic clinical services in a cost-effective and equitable manner. The project consists of the following components: 1) health system reorientation, which includes: (a) modernization of public health services, health promotion and disease prevention; (b) healthy children and safe motherhood; and (c) realignment of MOH; 2) rehabilitation and maintenance of health facilities and equipment; 3) development of health human resources; 4) modernization of the health financing system; and 5) project administration.
